Here's the reality facing President Trump's plan to slash corporate tax rates, one of the drivers of the postelection stock market rally that's pushed the Dow Jones industrial average above 20,000 and the Nasdaq Composite Index to record highs.The fate of this key Trump agenda item, meant to eliminate the tax disincentive for producing in the U.S. instead of overseas, likely rests on adoption of a 20% tax on imports — which retailers like Wal-Mart (WMT) and Best Buy (BBY) are dead-set on stopping and which likely would violate World Trade Organization rules.In other words, although Dow manufacturing components Boeing (BA), General Electric (GE) and other big exporters back tax reform that includes a border tax, it will surely face a bruising battle and, if it survives Congress, could spark a trade war.So the key question is this: As difficult and risky as this scenario sounds, why are House Republicans led by Speaker Paul Ryan so adamant about making a border tax central to tax reform? While they're surely sold on the merits of their approach, they also apparently realize that the most likely alternative to a border tax may be a brick wall for their dream of corporate tax reform.Start with the clearest manifestation that the U.S. corporate tax code is a mess: $2.5 trillion in profits and about $1.3 trillion in cash held overseas by U.S. companies — led by Dow techs Apple (AAPL) and Microsoft (MSFT) as well Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) — to avoid being taxed at the 35% federal tax rate (after a credit for foreign taxes paid). Tech giants account for a huge share held overseas by U.S. corporations, even as huge money spinners such as Apple and Alphabet minimize their effective tax rate by shifting intellectual property and other official profits to lower-tax jurisdictions.As it stands, the high U.S. corporate tax rate (39.1% when average state taxes are included) provides an incentive for companies to produce their products and earn their profits overseas, partly by using a variety of tax-avoidance strategies to magnify domestic costs and minimize domestic profits.Trump's campaign plan to cut the corporate tax rate all the way to 15% would have largely negated worries about American companies offshoring or engaging in tax-avoidance strategies because of relatively high U.S. tax rates. Yet his approach, which would add $1.4 trillion to the deficit over a decade, according to the conservative Tax Foundation, is a nonstarter in the Senate, where the GOP will need to come up with a plan that eventually pays for itself to pass via reconciliation.The House GOP would solve the budget problem by cutting the corporate tax rate only to 20% and by imposing a 20% tax on imports that the Tax Foundation says would raise $1.1 trillion over 10 years.The House approach would tax income where it is earned, so exports produced in the U.S. would be tax-free and profits earned overseas would face no U.S. tax. The upside of this approach is that it would eliminate any incentive for companies to shift income or production overseas for tax-avoidance purposes.IBD'S TAKE: Supporters of the border tax plan say that the dollar would rise by 20% vs. other currencies, meaning that it wouldn't harm either corporate profits or consumers. But it does pose a risk to U.S. investors holding shares of companies like Alibaba or international ETFs.Under the House approach, known as a territorial system, U.S. companies would no longer be at a disadvantage in selling abroad since they'll face the same local tax rate as their competitors.Yet it's easy to see how all of these positives would disappear without the $1.1 trillion raised by the import tax. All of a sudden, Republicans might be hard-pressed to cut the federal corporate tax rate even to 28%. At that point, it would be politically dicey to adopt a territorial tax system because it could arguably facilitate offshoring: Goods produced in the U.S. would still face a tax rate north of 30% (including state taxes) vs. 15% or lower in many other parts of the world.There's another problem. The House proposal is like a quarterback's long pass downfield to within the 20-yard-line of the opposing team. While some complex issues involving particular industries and phase-in periods would still have to be worked out, the main structure is fairly straightforward: Businesses would face a 20% tax on cash flow, defined as revenue minus cost of sales and capital expenses. Export sales would be eliminated from the top line, while import purchases would be eliminated from the cost of goods.Without a long "chunk yardage" play made possible by an export tax, getting the ball downfield would be a grind. Consider that among the biggest business tax breaks are credits for domestic manufacturing — probably the last thing Trump would want to eliminate; research and development; accelerated depreciation of capital investments; and the deduction of interest on corporate debt.While interest deductibility would go away in the House plan, raising the after-tax cost of investment, that's more than offset by other features of the plan that would cut the tax rate to 20%. Yet even if companies are allowed to immediately write off investments, Goldman Sachs economists have concluded that eliminating the interest deduction could slightly curtail investment "if the statutory rate does not decline sufficiently," which would defeat the point of tax reform.If Republicans can't go long with their border tax approach, then they'll have to claw their way downfield going inch by inch of the tax code. On the chance they could reach a consensus on small-ball tax reform that GOP lawmakers and the business community could support, there's a good chance that time would run out as the clock ticked down to the 2018 midterm elections.There are other approaches to major corporate tax reform that could work without the House's border-adjusted tax. But the alternatives, such as dramatically raising taxes on capital gains and dividends, are unlikely to unify Republicans and have gotten minimal attention. Republicans seem to have all their chips on the border tax."While complicated, border adjustment simplifies the rest of tax reform by avoiding dozens of fights over other offsets and deductions in the tax code," wrote Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Washington analyst Brian Gardner. "It is the linchpin for the GOP plan, and without it, the tax reform effort could collapse."Meanwhile, Goldman Sachs analysts see just a 20% chance of adoption for the border tax, which they believe "would ultimately be found to be WTO-noncompliant."Yet Goldman still sees a path to a 25% corporate rate, assuming congressional scorekeepers alter budget baselines to lower the bar to revenue neutrality, which would defy precedent and is probably wishful thinking. On top of a friendly baseline, the tax cut might be credited with bringing in several hundred billion in revenue via dynamic scoring. That might get the GOP almost into field-goal position, making it necessary to only grind out a manageable amount of additional savings to put some points on the board.RELATED:Trump's Bully Pulpit Isn't Stopping U.S. Firms From Shifting Jobs, Plants To MexicoWhy Tax Reform Could End In Tears For Trump And GOPTreasury Might Write Checks To Boeing Under GOP Tax ReformInvestors Would Pay For Corporate Tax Cut In New GOP Plan

The stock market looked to continue its winning ways after rebounding from early trading weakness.After initial declines, all three major indexes have now moved 0.2% higher through midday trading.Despite a hawkish tone from Fed Chair Janet Yellen, stocks have rebounded higher, setting new records, while financial stocks added to recent gains.Volume was tracking higher across both exchanges vs. the same time Monday.Within the Dow Jones industrial average, Goldman Sachs (GS) and JP Morgan (JPM) rose more than 1%. Nike (NKE) also moved up about 1%, reaching five-month highs.Apple (AAPL) advanced 1% as the stock continued to impress following its earnings release several weeks ago. Shares are now up 14% from its 118.12 cup-with-handle entry.Among U.S. automakers, General Motors (GM) soared more than 4% to reclaim its 50-day line after PSA Group, parent company of Peugot, announced it was in talks with General Motors to acquire its struggling Opel division. GM's Opel division includes its British Vauxhall brand.After making a bid for record highs, Tesla (TSLA) gave back part of its early gains. After being up as much as 2.4%, the stock settled up 0.8%. During its five-day winning streak, the electric-auto maker has risen 10%. The stock is extended from its 258.56 cup-with-handle entry.Retailers were moving up nicely in the stock market today after being consistent underperformers due to the disappointing holiday season.Best Buy (BBY) looked to reclaim its 50-day line after a 3.2% move higher. The retailer has been consolidating since December 2016.Kohl's (KSS) rose 3% as it looked to regain its 200-day line, which it lost when it gapped down on Jan. 5 following its dismal holiday sales announcement.On the downside, the energy sector was lagging the general market.Despite a rise in the price of crude oil, which is up 0.4%, oil and gas stocks found themselves at the bottom of the S&P 500's performers.Apache (APA) and Noble Energy (NBL) were two of the biggest losers, each falling more than 3%.Apache is consolidating below its 200-day line, while Noble reversed hard following its earning release after the bell on Monday.RELATED:GM Jumps On Talks To Sell European Unit Opel To PeugotTesla Stock Continues Drive Toward All-Time HighDow Stocks JPMorgan, Goldman Rise As Fed Signals More Hawkishness

The fight over the border tax has been focused entirely on the impact a 20% tax would have on big importers. Supporters insist that retailers like Wal-Mart (WMT) and Best Buy (BBY) wouldn't really be hurt, because currencies would adjust to neutralize the tax.Yet, while the predicted 25% rise in the dollar isn't certain — it could rise by somewhat less or even more — it's curious that there's been almost no attention paid to the potential impact on the one industry that's likely to bear the brunt of a currency adjustment: U.S. tourism.Tourism Economics estimates that each 10% rise in the dollar causes a 2% decrease in international visitors. On top of that, visitors may shorten their average stay and otherwise limit their spending.International travelers could find that visiting a Disney (DIS) theme park, gambling at an MGM Resorts (MGM) casino, staying at a Marriott (MAR) hotel or shopping at Tiffany (TIF) would be much more expensive.Staying at a Trump International Hotel would be more expensive too, which might influence President Trump's view that the dollar is already "too strong" and is "killing us." Just how much more expensive would depend on the extent to which reduced travel leads tourism-related industries to lower prices.Another hit would come from increased overseas travel by Americans, who would find that their dollars go much further in London, Paris, Rome and other destination spots around the world and opt against a U.S. vacation.International carriers like United Airlines (UAL) and American Airlines (AAL) may not suffer as much, since more outbound American travelers could ease the pain of fewer U.S.-bound tourists. Similarly, global hotel chains like Marriott may also see additional bookings by Americans abroad. But more domestic-focused businesses won't have such offsets.A major, unilateral increase in the U.S. currency could come at a pretty significant price. International travel added $247 billion to the U.S. economy last year and generated an $88 billion surplus, relative to what Americans spent abroad, according to the U.S. Travel Association's analysis of Commerce Department data. That's down from a $98 billion travel surplus in 2015. It's not clear how much of the narrower surplus was related to a stronger dollar, but there is generally a lag before shifts in currencies affect travel, given advance bookings.The figures include educational tourism — foreign students attending U.S. colleges and universities and generally paying much more than local residents to do so. With a 25% rise in the dollar, the U.S. might not look like quite as an attractive place to study. In 2015, education-related tourism totaled $35.8 billion."Regular exporters would, under border adjustment, receive a subsidy that would offset the exchange rate impact; but hotel owners presumably wouldn't," wrote American Enterprise Institute resident scholar Stan Veuger. "Or would U.S. taxpayers start subsidizing the vacations of Chinese tourists?"That seems as unlikely as federal government subsidies to let foreign students attend the University of California at Berkeley, he adds.While the impact on tourism has been almost entirely absent from the debate, it could play a bigger role as GOP senators decide whether they can back the House plan. Georgia Sen. David Perdue, former CEO of Dollar General (DG), has already signaled his fierce opposition, meaning just two more GOP defections could kill it.Expect Sen. Dean Heller of Nevada and Sen. Marco Rubio of Florida, who both represent top-five states for foreign travel, to come under heavy lobbying pressure from the tourism industry. Border states Texas and Arizona also are big tourism destinations, with Mexican travelers spending $19.7 billion in the U.S. in 2015.IBD'S TAKE: If the dollar appreciates 20% to 25% against foreign currencies, U.S. investors holding ADRs of foreign equities like Alibaba or international ETFs would take a hit.The projected rise in the dollar would come from already lofty levels. The U.S. dollar index, which measures the greenback against a basket of advanced-economy currencies, surged 26% from July 2014 to March 2015, hitting the highest level since 2003.On earnings calls in the fall of 2015, Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide noted "lower volumes of inbound international travelers due to the strong dollar," while Tiffany said it "continued to experience a negative effect on foreign tourists spending in the U.S."While the dollar eased off of those levels for most of 2016, it has strengthened again on expectations for a stronger U.S. economy under Trump.AEI's Veuger also points out that real estate is another "quasi-exporting" industry that might feel an impact from the border tax, since foreigners purchase some $100 billion worth of residential properties in a year, about half paid for in cash.RELATED:If Border Tax Dies, Trump Corporate Tax Cut May CollapseTreasury Might Write Checks To Boeing Under GOP Tax Reform

President Trump assured CEOs of Tesla Motors (TSLA), Ford (F) and U.S. Steel (X) on Monday that he'll definitely cut the corporate income-tax rate to 15% or 20%, yet Wall Street is closely watching to see if he can deliver.Doubts have crept in since Trump's dismissal last week of the leading House GOP corporate tax reform plan as "too complicated" and bound to boost the dollar that's already "too strong." Meanwhile, the House plan's 20% tax on imports has set off a fierce lobbying campaign from retailers like Wal-Mart (WMT), Target (TGT) and Best Buy (BBY), which fear that their tax bills would soar. Big tech importers like Apple (AAPL) would have to pay the 20% border tax and could also take a hit to foreign earnings as the dollar appreciates.But the newest Republican plan to sidestep a contentious debate over a border tax may drive home the reality that there aren't any politically easy ways of delivering a massive corporate tax cut, which might soften some of the criticism the House GOP is facing. The border tax would raise $1.1 trillion over a decade to help pay for the tax cut. The alternative proposed by Sen. Mike Lee of Utah would slash corporate taxes and pay for it by increasing tax rates on capital gains and dividends to offset much of the revenue loss."Taken together, these two changes would transfer the workers' share of the corporate tax onto American investors, who, again, are the natural and disproportionate beneficiaries of globalization relative to American workers," Lee wrote at The Federalist conservative blog.In other words, Lee's plan would deliver a big, beautiful cake to U.S. investors but wouldn't let them dig in.IBD'S TAKE: The House GOP tax reform that Trump is considering would likely help foreigners holding U.S. stocks and hit U.S. investors in foreign investments, such as Alibaba's ADRs or overseas ETFs.Economists figure that workers bear part of the burden of America's relatively high corporate income tax in lower wages, because it chases some investment to lower-tax locales. Lee, who hasn't put out a full-fledged plan, based his idea on a 2014 proposal from Alan Viard of the right-of-center American Enterprise Institute and Eric Toder of the left-leaning Tax Policy Center. Lee cites the 2014 version of their plan that cut the corporate income tax rate to zero and raised the tax rate on capital gains and dividends to the ordinary income rate of 42.4% (including a 3.8% ObamaCare tax on investments).Yet those authors revised their approach last year. To overcome the criticism that foreigners who owned shares of U.S. companies would escape any taxation, Viard and Toder decided to retain a corporate income-tax rate of 15%. Further, to avoid giving investors reason to hold onto their shares indefinitely to delay any tax payment, they would apply capital gains taxes based on the annual change in the market value of investors' equity holdings.Like the House GOP's border tax, the intent of their approach is to remove the tax code's incentive to produce overseas vs. in the U.S., or to shift profits to overseas subsidiaries through a variety of other strategies. Yet the lack of any colleagues on board may be a sign that there's even less support for taxing Americans' investments than foreign imports.RELATED:Wal-Mart, Best Buy, Apple Rally After Trump Pans GOP Border Adjustment Tax

Stock Below Buy PointJP Morgan upped its price target for the railroad stock to 55 from 44.Last week, news surfaced that former Canadian Pacific Railway (CP) chief Hunter Harrison was in talks to potentially lead the company, and that activist investor Mantle Ridge had asked for more than three seats on CSX's board.Shares advanced 0.9% to 47.68 in the stock market today.RELATED:Rail Vet Known For Improving Profits Could Soon Head CSXThe drugmaker got an upgrade to buy from neutral at Citigroup.But just late last week, Leerink analysts said that Biogen would trail Merck (MRK), AstraZeneca (AZN) and Eli Lilly (LLY) in introducing a BACE inhibitor to treat Alzheimer's.Shares climbed 0.5% to 266.11 intraday.RELATED:Biogen Trails Merck, Lilly In Alzheimer's; Hemophilia Spinoff Begins TradingBiogen Sidesteps Q4, 2016 Sales Misses On Strong Ex-Hemophilia GuideBernstein initiated coverage on a number of retailers, including membership warehouse Costco and big-box stores Wal-Mart and Target.Costco and Wal-Mart were both handed a market perform rating with 170 and 75 price target, respectively, while Target is an outperform in Bernstein's eyes, with a 77 price goal.Wal-Mart said Tuesday that it is dropping its version of Amazon (AMZN) Prime but will offer free two-day shipping for minimum orders of $35, matching the e-commerce giant.Meanwhile, Costco shares jumped on Thursday after reporting the best monthly same-store sales in over two years, a contrast to lackluster results from retail peers.Costco added 0.3% to 167.52, while Wal-Mart ticked up 0.7% to 66.89 and Target inched up 0.2% to 63.57.Bernstein also initiated coverage on Best Buy (BBY), Home Depot (HD) and Lowe's (LOW). Best Buy lost 1% to 43.53 while Lowe's was off 0.5% to 72.24. Home Depot ticked 0.1% higher to 136.65.RELATED:Costco Soars On Biggest Comparable Sales Gain In Over 2 YearsWal-Mart Offers Free 2-Day Shipping, Drops Amazon Prime Rival

After a solid month of bad news, Wal-Mart (WMT), Best Buy (BBY), Dollar Tree (DLTR) and other retail stocks were among the biggest winners on Tuesday as doubts emerged over President-elect Donald Trump's plan to slash corporate taxes.Apple (AAPL) also may be seeing a benefit from a disagreement between Trump and House Speaker Paul Ryan over how to make a big corporate tax cut fiscally viable.Even as doubts about tax reform helped drag down broad stock market indexes on Tuesday, retailers bucked the trend. Wal-Mart rose 1.9% to 68.42 on the stock market today. Best Buy climbed 2.4% to 44.88 and Dollar Tree jumped 3.1% to 79.51. Gap (GPS) rose 2.1% to 24.15.Meanwhile, Apple edged up 0.8% to 120, extending its breakout past a 118.12 buy point to a 14-month high.A plan backed by Ryan and other House GOP leaders would raise more than $1 trillion by imposing a 20% tax on imports, while making exports tax-free and lowering the federal corporate tax rate to 20%.Trump, in an interview with the Wall Street Journal published Monday, took issue with Ryan's approach. Trump criticized the border-adjusted tax as "too complicated" and said it could result in "a bad deal."While prospects for corporate tax reform have been one of the key drivers of the Trump stock market rally, financial markets and Wall Street analysts see Ryan's border-adjusted tax as bad news for big importers, with retailers especially hard hit. RBC Capital Markets analyst Scott Ciccarelli found that a 20% import tax could wipe out profits at Best Buy and raise Wal-Mart's tax bill by close to $10 billion.While Apple stands to be the biggest beneficiary of a reduced tax rate on profits held overseas, UBS analyst Steve Milunovich has estimated that the company could actually see an earnings drop under the full House GOP approach. Not only would the company face a tax on the value of iPhones it imports to sell in the U.S., but the value of foreign earnings could shrink in dollar terms.IBD'S TAKE: The House GOP tax reform that Trump is considering would likely help foreigners holding U.S. stocks and hit U.S. investors in foreign investments, such as Alibaba's ADRs or overseas ETFs.Trump's chief problem with Ryan's plan appears to be the consensus that a 20% tax on all imports would lead to a significant appreciation of the dollar vs. other currencies. In weekend comments, he specifically called out China and its weakening currency."Our companies can't compete with them now because our currency is too strong. And it's killing us," Trump said.Trump's comments sent the U.S. dollar index skidding 1.2%, while gold rose 1.6%. The 10-year Treasury yield fell to 2.33%, the lowest since late November, and closed below its 50-day moving average for the first time since late September.Trump has vowed to level the playing field for U.S.-based producers by imposing tariffs, threatening a 35% border tax on automakers producing in Mexico for the U.S. market.But he's skeptical of Ryan's approach because economists expect the 20% tax on imports to lead the U.S. dollar to appreciate vs. foreign currencies, neutralizing any competitive advantage from imposing an import tax.Trump's disagreement with Ryan raises a number of questions. If he doesn't back the border-adjusted tax plan, how will the GOP offset the cost of tax reform? Offsets are needed because legislation passed on a partisan basis in the Senate via reconciliation must be budget neutral after the 10th year.Further, does Trump's dismissal of Ryan's plan mean that he's more likely to make good on his threat to hit imports from Mexico and China with 35% to 45% tariffs? Such a fallback could pose even greater risks to retailers and Apple than the border adjustment tax.RELATED:Trump Trade, Tax Talk Hits Dollar As Mexico Warns On TariffsBank Stock Losses Intensify After Trump Rips GOP Tax Plan

The retail stock swoon picked up on Friday after getting started late in the session on Thursday, when the White House appeared to offer the clearest sign yet that President Trump may embrace the House GOP border-tax plan that could sock retailers' earnings.Shares of Target (TGT) fell 0.7% to 63.70 on the stock market today, retreating intraday to their lowest since November 2014. Wal-Mart (WMT) slid 1.6% to 65.66, hitting an eight-month low. Other retailers that have bucked the sector's recent woes also got caught in the downdraft. Costco (COST) slipped 1.2%, while Best Buy (BBY) sank 3.9%, falling below its 50-day line.Department stores were among the hardest hit. JCPenney (JCP) tumbled 4.7% to a 1-year low while Macy's (M) lost 2.7% for its worst close since late 2011.Shares of Amazon (AMZN) were relatively unscathed, easing 0.3% to 836.30, just below a buy point. The online shopping giant is seen as less exposed to a border tax, partly because of its fast-growing web services business and partly because import taxes would be borne by Amazon sellers responsible for shipping goods to the company's fulfillment centers.According to the initial news reports on Thursday afternoon, White House press secretary Sean Spicer seemed to offer confirmation that Trump would adopt the House proposal for a 20% tax on imports. Spicer said that the wall Trump wants to build on the border with Mexico could be paid for with a 20% tax on imports from Mexico as part of the broad corporate tax reform package being developed.While the White House later clarified that the border tax was only one option being considered, that apparently did little to assuage investors' concerns. Despite unexpectedly slow annualized fourth-quarter GDP growth of 1.9% reported on Friday, major stock indexes were essentially flat in afternoon trading, suggesting that politics were behind the retail walloping.IBD'S TAKE: Big exporters like Boeing could have a negative tax rate under the GOP tax reform plan.Wal-Mart and Target officials pleaded their case in Capitol Hill meetings this week. The National Retail Federation is lobbying aggressively to block the tax, which it says could lead to an outright decline in consumer spending.Economists generally suggest that such fears are way overblown because appreciation of the dollar vs. other currencies should offset the 20% tax. Nevertheless, retailers that were hoping for a big boost to after-tax profits from tax reform are now giving off a sense of panic about how they may fare under the GOP plan.House Republicans have said they see the border-adjusted tax, which applies to imports but not exports, as a critical part of tax reform because it would raise more than $1 trillion to help pay for a reduction in the corporate rate to 20%.RELATED:Trump Backs 20% Import Tax To Pay For Border Wall — Or NotU.S. Economic Malaise Hits 11 Years: GDP Growth 1.6% In 2016Why Tax Reform Could End In Tears For Trump And GOPWhy Trump Tax Reform Could Hurt Alibaba, Other ADRs

The Nasdaq composite led a broad advance in stocks on Thursday despite a big drop by former tech leader Cisco Systems (CSCO). Volume was mixed.Meanwhile, Apple (AAPL) showed resilience, giving back less than 0.2% after surging more than 2% on Wednesday. At 109.94, the biggest company by market value on either major U.S. exchange is still an arm's length away from potentially staging a re-breakout past a 110.33 cup with handle in a long bottoming base.Also positive for equities: recent breakouts are holding firm.The Nasdaq, which soared 3.8% last week, rose more than 0.7%, benefiting from strength not only in the tech sector but also airline, gaming, banking, financial, generic drug and hospital stocks.The S&P 500 gained 0.5% while the Dow Jones industrials lagged with a 0.2% lift. Volume rose on the Nasdaq and fell on the NYSE, according to preliminary data.The Russell 2000 rose nearly 0.6%.Nvidia (NVDA) continued its market-leading ways, but it cooled off a bit after rising to a new high of 94.79. The fabless designer of sophisticated chips to handle video graphics, machine learning and other data-intensive activity finished up 0.7% to 92.28.The IBD 50 and IBD Big Cap 20 name has gained more than 177% since breaking out past a 33.16 cup with handle buy point in heavy volume on March 18. Nvidia qualifies a large cap with a market value of $49 billion. In comparison, industry peer Intel (INTC) weighs in at $166 billion.Apple is up around 2% year to date, thus lagging the major indexes by a few percentage points. But for current shareholders, the iPhone giant and incredible winner from 2004 to 2012 has not triggered any sell signals lately. The stock's recent new uptrend remains intact.The bigger questions an investor should ask are:1) Will the stock stay trapped between its 50- and 200-day moving averages? (The 50-day line is painted in red in IBD charts, the 200-day in black.)2) Will its Accumulation/Distribution Rating, currently a poor D+ as seen in IBD Stock Checkup, improve over the next few weeks?And finally, 3) Does the company stand a good chance of beating Q1 profit views and reverse its three-quarter slide in earnings?Perhaps the excellent gain by Best Buy (BBY) is a good omen, since Apple sells a ton of iPads, Macbooks, and iPhones at the leading consumer electronics retail chain. Best Buy soared more than 14% to 46.34 in nearly five times normal volume following a 51% leap in fiscal third-quarter earnings to 62 cents a share, pounding views by more than 30%.Revenue rose 1% to $8.95 billion, ending a four-quarter streak of year-over-year declines or flat sales. Net margin rose 60 basis points to 2.2%.Best Buy is now sharply extended past a 40.68 base on base buy point. The RS Rating jumped to 94 from 87 in a single day thanks to Thursday's buying rush, and it indicates Best Buy has the potential to emerge as a new market leader.Elsewhere in the stock market today, Argan (AGX) continued to act right after a recent breakout past a 60.19 flat base buy point. The specialist in engineering, construction and telecom infrastructure rose 3% to 62.70 and is thus still in buy range.The 5% chase zone extends up to 63.19. Argan's initial breakout came on June 8 when shares blasted past a 35.50 early entry within a long saucer-type pattern.Notice how in the weekly chart of Argan (a daily chart is shown here), the two most recent down weeks in price came in light volume, a sign that eagerness to sell among institutional investors has waned.The Street sees FY 2017 profit jumping 50% to $3.62 a share, which would be an annual record.In the IBD 50, Applied Materials (AMAT) slipped 1% in after-hours trading following robust October-ended fiscal Q4 results that missed the Street's top-line forecast. The chipmaking gear titan reported accelerating revenue growth of 39% to $3.3 billion, just shy of the $3.31 billion consensus view.Earnings per share rose 128% to 66 cents a share, beating the 20-analyst consensus estimate of 65 cents by a penny. The results marked a third quarter in a row of accelerating growth, a typical sign of a stock market leader. Earnings per share dropped 4% in the quarter ended January 2016, then revved up 17% and 52% the next two quarters as revenue went from a 4% dip to flat sales, then 13% growth.Thursday's action in Applied Materials was bullish; the stock rose more than 2% to 30.73, just shy of a potential eight-week flat-base breakout at 31.17.As of Thursday, Applied ranked No. 45 in the IBD 50.Elsewhere, gym operator Planet Fitness (PLNT)dropped hard on a share offering announcement late Wednesday. The stock sank 4.6% to 23.01, but held up above a 22.25 cup-with-handle pivot point.Planet Fitness gained as much as 13% following last week's breakout. When a stock rises 10% or more from a proper buy point, it's key to defend the gain and not let it turn into a loss. One can always buy the stock back again when demand returns.Planet Fitness plans to sell 15 million common shares. That would narrow the gap between its current float of 31 million shares and 98 million total shares outstanding.RELATED:Did Trump's Election Victory Set The Stage For A  New Secular Bull Market?When Did Planet Fitness Break Out?A Big Earnings Jump For Applied Materials; So, What's Next?

Stocks opened mildly higher Thursday, following a raft of positive jobs and housing market data and ahead of this morning's testimony by Fed chief Janet Yellen before Congress.The Dow industrials and Nasdaq rose 0.1% while the S&P 500 added 0.2%.The stock market today will have all ears on comments from and questions asked of Chairwoman Yellen by Congress, scheduled for a 10 a.m. ET start. It will be the Fed chair's first visit to Capitol Hill since the election of Donald Trump as president and the affirmation of the Republican majority in the House and Senate, with the questioning expected to be rigorous.Meanwhile, New York Federal Reserve Bank President William Dudley is scheduled to speak before a conference in New York at 8:50 a.m. ET.Overseas trading laid low ahead of Yellen's commentary. China's markets were mixed, up and down only 0.1%. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 ended flat. Benchmark indexes in Frankfurt and Paris were also mixed in a very tight range entering afternoon trade, and London's FTSE 100 added 0.2%.Earnings reports drove stocks all over the map, with retail and shipping being early centers of activity.Best Buy (BBY) leapt 6% after reporting third-quarter results. Staples (SPLS) was up a fraction.Wal-Mart (WMT) dragged 3% lower. The big box retailer's third-quarter earnings slipped less than projected by analysts. Revenue rose 1%, just shy of expectations, and midpoints for management's fourth-quarter and full-year earnings guidance were below consensus views. Wal-Mart shares are working on the right side of a possible base pattern.Cisco Systems (CSCO) dropped 6%, hurt by a fiscal first-quarter report late Wednesday that showed better-than-expected earnings and revenue, but second-quarter guidance was below consensus. Cisco has been working on building a flat base since early September.NetApp (NTAP) skipped up 10%, soaring on adjusted fiscal second-quarter earnings that fell less than analysts expected. Revenue undercut expectations by a narrow margin and management offered third-quarter earnings guidance well above views and revenue in line with consensus views. The data storage specialist broke out from a cup base with a buy point of 36.20.The rally in shipping stocks continued, with Dryships (DRYS) up 58% in premarket trading but halted in regular trading. Sino Global Shipping (SINO) soared 80%. Euroseas (ESEA) spiked 25%. Aegean Marine Petroleum (ANW) hopped up 13%. Seanergy Maritime Holdings (SHIP) rose 6%.Consumer prices gained 0.4% in October, the Labor Department said, an uptick from September's 0.3% increase and in line with consensus expectations. Core prices, minus energy and food, added 0.1%, equal to the prior month's move and below views for a 0.2% increase.Initial unemployment claims slumped sharply to 235,000 in the week ended Nov. 12, down from 254,000 claims in the prior week and sharply undercutting estimates for an uptick to 257,000 claims. The four-week moving average also dipped sharply, its first decrease in five weeks.Housing starts surged to an annualized rate of 1.323 million in October, according to the Commerce Department, vs. an upwardly revised tally of 1.054 million starts in September. The number easily topped economist projections for a rate of 1.168 new starts. Building permits, which gauge upcoming activity, rose to an annualized pace of 1.229 million. That was slightly above September's rate, but well above consensus views for permits issued at a rate of 1.190 million.Manufacturing in the mid-Atlantic region slowed in November, reducing the Philadelphia Federal Reserve's Manufacturing Business Outlook Survey to 7.6, vs. a 9.7 reading in September. Economists had expected a decrease to a reading of 8.0. New orders and shipments increased, the report said, and delivery times and unfilled orders were positive, but employment categories lagged.Crude oil futures gained more than 1%, sending West Texas Intermediate back above $46 a barrel. Gold was up a fraction to just below $1,225 an ounce. The dollar was mixed, down vs. the pound and the euro, but up against the yen.  Bonds eased, lifting the 10-year-yield 2 basis points to 2.25%.RELATED:Cisco Guidance Misses; CEO Blames 'Wait-And-See' Telecoms Post-TrumpFed's Yellen: Rate Hike "Appropriate Relatively Soon"

Tech stocks were in the driver's seat again for the third straight session Thursday as Wall Street weighed strong housing data, more earnings reports and comments from Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen.However, data networking gear stalwart Cisco Systems (CSCO) and retailing giant Wal-Mart (WMT) lagged in the Dow after reporting earnings. Cisco slumped nearly 6% and Wal-Mart gave back 3%.Nasdaq 100 component NetApp (NTAP) gapped up over a 36.20 buy point but gave back early gains. Shares still rose 7% after the maker of network storage and data management hardware reported better-than-expected earnings late Wednesday.The Nasdaq composite added 0.5%, the S&P 500 rose 0.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average was mostly unchanged. Volume on the Nasdaq was tracking slightly higher than Wednesday's level in the stock market today. NYSE volume was on pace to be slightly lower.In economic news, U.S. new-home construction jumped to a nine-year high in October, weekly jobless claims dropped 19,000 to 235,000, a sign that the U.S. labor market is getting tighter. Economists expected a small increase to 257,000.Meanwhile, in testimony before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, Yellen reinforced expectations of a rate hike at the Dec. 14 meeting. Currently, futures traders think there's a 90% chance of it happening, according to data from the CME Group.Among the day's movers, consumer electronics retailer Best Buy (BBY) gapped up over a 40.31 buy point, jumping 13% to 45.70. The stock opened at 42.93 and was in buying range for awhile but not anymore. A big earnings beat was the catalyst, helped by strong sales of televisions and related home theater products, mobile phones, wearables and connected home devices.MaxLinear (MXL) outperformed in the IBD 50, rising 4% to 22.15. It's still in buy range from a 21.52 cup-with-handle buy point. Nvidia (NVDA) also did well with a nearly 2% gain. Shares soared 30% last week on strong earnings, but the stock is close to moving above an upper channel line which would be a sell signal for those with a big profit in the stock. Elsewhere, Middleby (MIDD) continued work on the right side of a base as shares rose around 3%. The stock is working on its sixth straight gain after reporting earnings last week. Earnings growth has averaged 32% over the past four quarters. Sales growth has averaged 28% over the same time period. Middleby  makes commercial food service, food processing, and residential kitchen equipment.After the close, watch for earnings results from Applied Materials (AMAT) and Ross Stores (ROST). Applied Materials is working on a shallow, cup-shaped base with a 31.17 buy point. Shares were recently trading around 30.55. Ross Stores' flat base currently shows a 66.38 buy point. Shares were recently trading around 66.38.December WTI crude oil futures were recently trading around $45.28 a barrel, down 0.6%. The 10-year Treasury yield added 5 basis points to 2.27%.RELATED:Fed's Yellen: Rate Hike 'Soon,' Will Serve Full TermEconomy Gets A Thumbs Up On Jobs, Homes, Factories And InflationHow Much Would A Six-Month Cut In OPEC Output Actually Help Oil?Are We Approaching The Dawn Of A Secular New Bull Market?

Here's your Investing Action Plan for Thursday: what you need to know as an investor for the coming day. Earnings season is running dry, but the few companies that are reporting, like Applied Materials (AMAT), Wal-Mart (WMT) and Ross Stores (ROST), could provide actionable signals. Best Buy (BBY) is already in buy zone, and Salesforce (CRM) also reports. Meanwhile, Federal Reserve…

Boeing (BA) is going to bat for the BAT — the border adjustment tax that is a central part of the GOP plan to cut the corporate tax rate.The controversial Republican tax-reform plan, which would slap a 20% tax on imports but make exports tax-free, has gotten off to a rough start in the court of public opinion. The National Retail Federation has warned that it would raise prices and cause consumer spending to decline, while analysts have said that big importers like Wal-Mart (WMT), Target (TGT) and Best Buy (BBY) could suffer major hits to profitability.House Republicans, with the help of economists, have countered that an anticipated 20% appreciation of the dollar would neutralize those negative effects, while removing what they call a "Made in America" tax.Now big exporters including Boeing and General Electric (GE) are reportedly gearing up to help House Speaker Paul Ryan make that case, and it's not hard to understand why.Consider Boeing: The company paid an effective federal tax rate of 27.7% in 2015, when it had a current tax bill of $2.1 billion, but would have had negative tax liability under the House plan.In 2015, 59% of company revenue came from non-U.S. customers. Given that Boeing does almost all of its manufacturing and sourcing within the U.S., it has limited exposure to the 20% import tax. Meanwhile, the House GOP tax plan exempts exports from any tax. Companies would be taxed on their cash flow, basically the total cost of (non-imported) goods, labor and capital outlays minus U.S. revenue.In effect, Boeing's U.S. cash flow, as far as the GOP tax plan is concerned, would have been dramatically negative once its $56.7 billion in non-U.S. revenue was excluded.IBD'S TAKE: The House GOP tax reform that Trump is considering would likely help foreigners holding U.S. stocks and hit U.S. investors in foreign investments, such as Alibaba's ADRs or overseas ETFs.Morgan Stanley analysts wrote in December that some big exporters "may pay little or no federal taxes — and may even accrue tax benefits in the form of net operating losses."Yet some tax experts say the only way to make the House plan work as intended would be for the federal government to write a check to exporters with negative liability.The border adjustment tax would effectively become a trade barrier, doing more to keep out imports than to facilitate exports "unless cash refunds were provided," wrote American Enterprise Institute scholar Alan Viard.William Gale, co-director of the Tax Policy Center, wrote that while it may create a "serious optics problem" for Treasury to write checks to big corporations, the issue is just one of perception. Because of the exchange-rate adjustment, the House plan shouldn't affect the after-tax profitability of either exporters or importers, he wrote.President Trump initially sounded wary of Ryan's tax reform approach, calling it "too complicated" and the wrong medicine for a dollar that is already "too strong." But he may have put those concerns aside: White House spokesman Sean Spicer said Thursday that Trump would pay to build a wall on the Mexican border with funds generated by a 20% border tax as part of tax reform. But White House chief of staff Reince Priebus later said a 20% tax is just one option.The outcome of this rhetorical and political battle may be critical in deciding whether Trump can deliver on his plan to cut the corporate tax rate to a range of 15% to 20% from a statutory rate of 35%, among the world's highest. Without the $1.1 trillion in revenue that would come from the border-adjusted tax, analysts say a tax rate of 25% may be the best Trump can do.Boeing shares fell fractionally to close at 167.70 Friday on the stock market today. But they're up nearly 6% for the week, hitting new highs after the aerospace giant topped earnings views.RELATED:President Trump Backs 20% Import Tax To Pay For Border Wall, Aide SaysWal-Mart, Best Buy, Apple Rally After Trump Pans GOP Border Adjustment Tax

After vowing a border tax, then calling it "too complicated," then saying it was still being considered, President Trump told a group of CEOs Monday that the U.S. will incentivize domestic production and impose a "very major" tax on goods that American companies produce overseas.During a meeting with a manufacturing advisory group, Trump also reiterated pledges to slash regulations and income taxes.Afterward, Ford (F) CEO Mark Fields told reporters the meeting was positive. The carmaker had earlier canceled plans to build a new plant in Mexico. While Trump criticized Ford during the campaign for making cars there, the company said canceling the plant was due to lack of demand for small cars.Others at the meeting included CEOs of Tesla Motors (TSLA), Under Armour (UA), Lockheed Martin (LMT), Arconic (ARNC), Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) and U.S. Steel (X). The advisory panel is led by Dow Chemical's (DOW) CEO.Shares of Ford closed down 0.4% on the stock market today. General Motors (GM) and Fiat Chrysler (FCAU), which also have Mexico operations but recently pledged major U.S. investments, fell 1% and rose 2.7%, respectively. The CEOs of the three carmakers will also meet with Trump Tuesday at the White House. Tesla relies on a U.S.-based factory for final production and rallied 1.7%.Retail giant Wal-Mart (WMT), which relies heavily on imports, finished 0.8% lower, and Target (TGT) lost 0.4%.IBD'S TAKE: The House GOP tax reform that Trump is considering would likely help foreigners holding U.S. stocks and hit U.S. investors in foreign investments, such as Alibaba's ADRs or overseas ETFs.In an interview published last Monday, Trump told the Wall Street Journal the border-adjusted tax plan was "too complicated" and could result in "a bad deal," sending shares of Wal-Mart, Best Buy (BBY) and Macy's (M) higher.The next day, Trump told Axios the border tax, which is a key element in the congressional GOP's tax strategy, is "certainly something that's going to be discussed."RELATED:Wal-Mart, Best Buy, Apple Rally After Trump Pans GOP Border Adjustment TaxTrump Trade, Tax Talk Hits Dollar As Mexico Warns On Tariffs Wal-Mart, Target, Macy's Drop Amid Tariff Talk: Investing Action Plan

Online shoppers are swarming to Amazon.com (AMZN) this holiday season and the e-commerce giant has gained share vs. Best Buy (BBY), Wal-Mart (WMT) and Apple (AAPL), says market research firm Slice Intelligence.But Amazon and the other FANG stocks — Facebook (FB), Netflix (NFLX) and Alphabet (GOOGL), the parent company of Google — mostly fell in the stock market today, while Apple rose a small fraction.Slice late Thursday said some 45.5% of consumer online spending went to Amazon in the week ended Dec. 17, up from 42.3% the previous week.Best Buy had 2.9% of online spending, with Wal-Mart and Apple both at 2.6%, says the market tracker.Slice Intelligence says electronics, as usual, are the top product category, followed by apparel. Apple orders had the highest average price tag at $350.IBD'S TAKE: Apple and most of the FANG stocks are showing weak relative strength vs. the broader market. True market leaders show rising RS lines. To find stocks with RS lines hitting new highs, take a free MarketSmith trial.Amazon may be getting a boost from improved logistics, with the average package for all online sellers arriving in just three days, compared to five days in 2015.Morgan Stanley, in a research report, says Amazon's fast-growing Prime membership will also likely drive a strong holiday season.Apple and the FANG stocks have largely sat out the stock market rally since Republican Donald Trump's surprise election as president. Investors have poured money into other sectors expected to benefit from infrastructure spending, lighter regulation and tax cuts.A strong holiday season could help Amazon stock, which touched a low of 719 on Nov. 14. Amazon stock, though, fell 0.75% Friday to 760.59. Amazon stock has been consolidating and trades near its 50-day moving average with a buy point of 847.31.Apple stock has formed a cup pattern and is nearing a buy point of 118.79. Apple stock edged up 0.2% Friday to 116.52.Netflix remains on the IBD Leaderboard of top-performing stocks. Netflix is drawing near a 129.39 cup-with-handle buy point, but rose just a penny, to 125.59, on Friday.Facebook stock is trading below its 50-day moving average. Facebook Chairman and CEO Mark Zuckerberg sold nearly 800,000 shares in the social media company as part of a preplanned sale. Facebook has a buy point of 133.60, but it fell 0.11% Friday to 117.27.Alphabet stock was upgraded on Wednesday by Aegis Capital with a 980 price point on views that margin pressure will ease on advertising products. Alphabet stock is trading above its 50-day moving average with a buy point of 839.10. Shares of Alphabet, though, slipped 0.23% Friday, to 807.80.RELATED:Trump, Silicon Valley Shake Hands; Amazon's Bezos Hails 'Productive' MeetingWill Trump's China Bully Pulpit Backfire On Tech Firms?

The holidays were happy ones for Amazon.com (AMZN), which says that its very own hardware products, led by the Echo Dot, were its best-selling products.Following the Echo Dot, Amazon said the best-selling products over the holiday season overall were the Fire TV Stick, the Fire Tablet and the Amazon Echo.Amazon says it has sold "millions" of the Echo Dot since its introduction. The Echo Dot, which costs $49.99, is the low-end version of the Amazon Echo, which sells for $179.99. The Echo, including Dot, is a voice activated, Wi-Fi-connected smart speaker linked to the cloud. With the voice of the artificially intelligent Alexa, Echo serves up music, news, traffic and weather, plays games, answers questions and does much more.Amazon stock was up 1.5% near 772 in afternoon trading in the stock market today, just below its 50-day moving average.The Amazon Echo, a similar device by the Google unit of Alphabet (GOOGL) and another being developed by Microsoft (MSFT) are expected to play a key role in the smart home. Alphabet recently followed Amazon with the introduction of Google Home, which sells for $129. Google Home is a voice-activated speaker powered by Google Allo, its artificially intelligent assistant.IBD'S TAKE: The battle to provide the best digital butler for homes is one that Amazon and other tech leaders will be fighting for years. These in-home devices with artificial intelligence and language processing skills could evolve into the next major disruption in computing and put the smart home on a fast track.Microsoft has yet to introduce a similar device for the home, but it has deep roots in artificial intelligence with its Cortana platform, available on mobile devices and PCs. This is also true of Apple with its Siri platform and Facebook (FB) with its Messenger platform.Microsoft last week gave a sneak peak at a new hardware device that looks similar to Echo. The device has the Harman (HAR) label but is voice-controlled through Cortana.Among other top-selling products on Amazon over the holiday sales period were memory cards from Western Digital (WDC)-owned SanDisk, wearable technology from Garmin (GRMN), Samsung TVs, Levi's and Spalding basketballs.Online shoppers swarmed to Amazon this holiday season. The the e-commerce leader has gained share vs. Best Buy (BBY), Wal-Mart (WMT) and Apple (AAPL).Amazon said more than 72% of Amazon customers worldwide shopped using a mobile device this holiday.RELATED:Amazon Introduces 'Amazon Go' Retail Stores, No Checkout, No LinesAmazon Set To Disrupt Retailers In Apparel, Groceries, ServicesApple, Microsoft, Alphabet Are Kings Of Cash As Tech Sector Rules

The U.S. economy expanded at a 3.2% annual rate in the third quarter, the Commerce Department said Tuesday. That's the strongest growth since the second quarter of 2014 and revised up slightly from the initial reading of a 2.9% gain.Economists had expected a 3.1% revised reading.Consumer spending rose at a 2.8% pace, faster than the initial reading of 2.1%. .Separately, the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index shot up 8.5 points in November to 107.1, the highest since July 2007 and much better than views for a rise to 101. The reading, which reflects post-election sentiment, showed consumers are more upbeat about current and future conditions for business and jobs.Together with the GDP data, the report bodes well for consumers' willingness to spend this holiday season.Initial readings on holiday spending have been mixed. In-store sales over the Thanksgiving weekend fell particularly sharply, though that partly reflects a shift to online shopping and retailers offering deals throughout November and December.Online holiday sales are booming, growing even stronger than expected. That should be good news for Amazon (AMZN), which has outstripped e-commerce growth in recent years. But Target (TGT), Best Buy (BBY), Wal-Mart (WMT) and other retailers are putting more effort than ever on online sales.IBD'S TAKE: Stock markets have rallied on hopes for Trump's tax and spending plans, but here's why economists are wary of Trumpnomics.Apple (AAPL) products have been big sellers, with Target and Best Buy offering deep discounts on Apple iPads. Samsung 4K TVs have also been hot.Business investment on structures was revised up sharply, though spending on equipment and software was revised down. Net exports boomed in Q3, though largely on soybean exports. Residential investment was revised to a smaller 4.4% decline.Meanwhile, the S&P/Case-Schiller 20-city home price index for September rose 0.4% vs. August, matching economists' expectations. Home values ros 5.1% vs. a year earlier, just below forecasts for 5.2%.The Case-Schiller index is considered one of the most comprehensive for home prices, but it is backward looking. Even's September's data will reflect a three-month moving average.Meanwhile, mortgage rates rose along with Treasury yields in recent months, especially after the presidential election. Investors are betting on Federal Reserve rate hikes and perhaps higher inflation.Apple shares fell 0.1% on the stock market today, still trading modestly below their 50-day moving average. Amazon slid 0.55%, also finding resistance at the 50-day line. Target, Best Buy and Wal-Mart rose less than 1%.On Thursday, the Institute for Supply Management will release its November manufacturing index, while automakers will release U.S. sales figures. On Friday, the Labor Department will release its employment report for November.

Major index-tracking ETFs retreated from their stunning postelection rally on Cyber Monday despite a surge in oil prices and amid mixed news tied to holiday shoppers.SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) slipped 0.5% on the stock market today.This exchange traded fund serves as a proxy for the broad U.S. market and set a fresh all-time high of 221.56 last week.Energy Select Sector SPDR (XLE), which tracks energy stocks in the S&P 500, booked a 1.4% loss despite strong gains in the price of West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures for January delivery. WTI settled 84 cents higher at $46.90 a barrel.Oil rose on reports that Iraq will lend support to the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) in its efforts to curb or freeze production at a Wednesday meeting.Defensive sectors, such as real estate, consumer staples and utilities, advanced. Most other S&P 500 sectors tracked lower, weighing on ETFs holding the related stocks.However, Technology Select Sector SPDR (XLK) nudged up 0.1%, scoring a fresh high of 48.26 intraday.In total, 13 ETFs focused on diversified exposure to technology stocks or targeted exposure to chipmakers posted 52-week highs. However, trading volume was lackluster and many of these funds closed flat to lower.Among them, iShares PHLX Semiconductor (SOXX) and SPDR S&P Semiconductor (XSD) saw their relative strength (RS) lines pierce new high ground.Retailers Amazon.com (AMZN), Best Buy (BBY), Macy's (M), Wal-Mart (WMT), Target (TGT), Nordstrom (JWN) were in focus as some analysts lowered their holiday outlook on Monday.Tech giants Apple (AAPL) and Alphabet (GOOGL) — as well as their parts suppliers — may benefit from new product releases, including the iPhone 7, MacBook Pro and the Pixel phone.Many retailers, such as Best Buy, offer exceptional bargains on Apple products and other tech items on the Monday following Thanksgiving, known as Cyber Monday.Online retailers like Amazon saw better results than the traditional brick-and-mortar retailers this past holiday weekend, according to the National Retail Federation.IBD'S TAKE: Looking for stocks that are at or near proper buy points? Apple, Amazon, Best Buy, Ulta Beauty are stocks to watch. Some ETFs holding these stocks also are within buy range.Here's a look at the performance of major exchange traded funds across key asset classes on the stock market today.The RS (Relative Price Strength) rating measures a stock's price performance over the last 12 months vs. all stocks and ETFs, on a scale of 1 to a best-possible 99.SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), -0.5%, RS 54PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), -0.2%, RS 54SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA), -0.3%, RS 59IShares Core S&P Mid-Cap (IJH), -0.7%, RS 65IShares Russell 2000 (IWM), -1.3%, RS 71IShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), -0.5%, RS 31Vanguard FTSE Emerging Markets (VWO), +0.5%, RS 49SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), +1.1%, RS 28United States Oil (USO), +1.1%, RS 22IShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond (AGG), +0.4%, RS 31PowerShares DB U.S.$ Bullish (UUP), -0.3%, RS 51IPath S&P 500 VIX Short-Term Futures (VXX), +0.9%, RS 1

Will it be a blue Christmas for consumer electronics vendors?Recent downbeat guidance from Fitbit (FIT) and GoPro (GPRO) points to a crummy holiday season for those gadget makers. The big question is whether other consumer electronics vendors will end up with coal in their stockings this quarter.Consumer electronics is a top sales category for the holidays. And it could be that Fitbit wearable activity trackers and GoPro action cameras have simply fallen out of favor with shoppers.As retailers and device makers prepare for the traditional kickoff of the holiday selling season on Black Friday, analysts are placing their bets on what the big gadgets will be this Christmas.Consumer electronics retailer Best Buy (BBY) likely will provide some commentary on what it sees as big sellers in the December quarter, when it releases fiscal third-quarter earnings on Thursday before the market open.IBD'S TAKE: Institutional money was rotating into new sectors after a wacky few days for stock markets following Donald Trump's surprise presidential win, but one thing remained constant: Facebook continued to be an IBD Leaderboard stock. This is the place to go to find leading stocks, which includes the social network leader even though a 5.6% drop on Nov. 3 triggered a sell signal for some investors. But it's more complex than that, as Leaderboard can explain.This past Thursday, Best Buy revealed its Thanksgiving weekend door-buster specials designed to entice consumers to come to its stores. It's offering steep discounts on 4K ultrahigh-definition televisions from the likes of LG, Samsung and Sony (SNE); ultraportable notebook PCs from Microsoft (MSFT), HP (HPQ) and others; and video game consoles bundled with software.The Consumer Technology Association predicts that U.S. holiday spending — covering all of November and December — on tech products will rise 3.1% this year to $36.05 billion, after rising just 1.4% last year.CTA Chief Economist Shawn DuBravac told IBD that retailers and consumer electronics makers waited until after the presidential election to begin advertising for the holiday season.The most popular tech item on holiday shopping lists this year is headphones, driven by the shift to wireless audio devices, DuBravac said. Other desired tech gifts include laptops, TVs, smartphones, tablets and video game consoles.Some 40% of shoppers plan to buy headphones as gifts this holiday season, according to a CTA survey.Apple (AAPL) has helped fuel the move to wireless headsets with its bold decision not to include an analog audio port on its iPhone 7 smartphones. It is selling Beats brand wireless headphones and will soon debut its AirPods wireless earbuds.Several vendors are looking to take on Bose this holiday in the subcategory of noise-canceling wireless headphones, Marjorie Costello, editor and publisher of Consumer Electronics Online News, told IBD.Bose released its QuietComfort 35 headphones for $349 in June. Sony followed in September with its MDR 1000X headphones for $399. And Plantronics (PLT) released its BackBeat Pro 2 headphones for $199 in October."Those are not inexpensive gifts, but they're really good gifts to give anyone who travels," Costello said. Headphones are a no-brainer gift "because everyone has ears," she said.Emerging product categories likely to see a boost in sales this year are drones, virtual reality headsets and smart home devices, DuBravac said.The CTA predicts about 1.2 million drones will be sold this holiday season, up 112% over 2015. That's despite the fact that GoPro issued a product recall and stopped sales of its just-released Karma drone. Market leader DJI is likely to benefit from consumer demand for flying-camera drones, such as its Mavic Pro quadcopter.The trade group forecasts sales of 700,000 VR headsets this holiday season. Those include premium VR headsets from Sony and Facebook's (FB) Oculus unit, as well as lower-cost smartphone-based headsets from Samsung and Alphabet (GOOGL)-owned Google.But NPD analyst Stephen Baker expects VR headset sales will be "lukewarm" this holiday season. "VR will elicit a tepid response from consumers," he said in a report.The CTA also is looking for higher sales of smart-home devices this season, including voice-activated digital assistants such as Amazon.com's (AMZN) Echo and Google Home.Voice-enabled smart speakers that can play music on command, answer spoken questions and perform other tasks will be in high demand this holiday, NPD's Baker said.Ultra HD, or 4K, televisions will dominate Black Friday and Thanksgiving weekend sales, Baker said. Such TVs, led by sales of sets with screen sizes of 55 inches and larger, will account for 60% of TV dollars spent this holiday, he said.Holiday shipments of 4K TVs in the U.S. are expected to reach 4.5 million units, the CTA said. The trade group predicts full-year sales of 4K TVs will rise 40% over 2015 to hit 10 million units.PC sales, meanwhile, will be the best in at least four years this holiday as consumers upgrade to sleek new models, Baker said.Among product categories likely to disappoint this holiday is wearables, Baker said."While prices for wearables may begin to decrease (especially in the fitness segment where competition is growing), expect a slight slowdown in sales as consumer interest fades," Baker said. That would be bad news for market leader Fitbit, which provided weak Q4 guidance.Another category facing a slowdown is action cameras, a market dominated by GoPro with its Hero cameras. The market for wearable sports cameras has matured and sales overall are poised to decline, DuBravac said.Other new products hoping to make a splash this holiday season are Snapchat's Spectacles, $130 sunglasses with a built-in camera; Apple's second-generation Apple Watch with new fitness features; and upgraded versions of existing game consoles, including Microsoft's Xbox One S and Sony's PlayStation 4 Pro and PS4 Slim.RELATED:Google Home To Overtake Amazon's Smart Echo By 2020: IHSSony PlayStation VR Aims To Make Virtual Reality MainstreamTeens Stoked About iPhone 7, But GoPro Is So Yesterday

Here's your weekly Investing Action Plan: what you need to know as an investor for the coming week. Markets will focus on OPEC's meeting and the November U.S. jobs report, which could propel stocks further into record territory or drag down increasingly lofty sentiment. Ambarella (AMBA), Autodesk (ADSK), Ulta Beauty (ULTA) and Kroger (KR) will highlight earnings news, while automakers…

Despite competition for consumer dollars from 4K TVs and drones, Apple (AAPL) is expected to be one of the winners this holiday season, Drexel Hamilton analyst Brian White said in a research report Monday."Apple remains one of the best positioned tech companies to benefit from spending trends this holiday season with a well-received iPhone 7/7 Plus, a new Apple Watch (Series 2, ceramic Apple Watch Edition, Apple Watch Nike+) and a new MacBook Pro with Touch Bar," White said. "If Apple launches its new AirPods for the holidays, we expect this gift to be a very popular stocking stuffer."Apple's wireless earbuds, called AirPods, were expected to launch in late October, but were delayed for some last-minute improvements. Apple's website lists the $159 product as "coming soon."The holiday shopping season officially kicks off this weekend with Thanksgiving evening and Black Friday doorbuster sales.The National Retail Federation is projecting overall holiday sales to grow by 3.6% this season to $655.8 billion and above the 3.2% growth seen in 2015, while also higher than the seven-year average increase of 3.4%.The Consumer Technology Association predicts consumer-electronics sales will rise by 3.1% this holiday season, vs. 1.4% growth in the November-December period last year.This holiday season, the CTA expects strong U.S. sales of drones (1.2 million units, up 112% year over year), virtual reality headsets (700,000 units) and 4K ultra-high-definition televisions (4.5 million units).The top tech products on gift wish lists include notebook computers (11%), TVs (8%), smartphones (8%), tablets (7%) and video-game consoles (5%), according to a consumer survey by CTA. There also is interest in smartwatches (3%), VR headsets (2%), home robotic vacuums (2%) and portable GPS (2%), CTA said.Best Buy (BBY) signaled strong holiday tech sales when it reported better-than-expected fiscal third-quarter results last week. The consumer-electronics retailer was helped in Q3 by the launch of Apple's iPhone 7 and robust sales of 4K TVs and home theater systems.Discount retailer Target (TGT) also pointed to a merry holiday season ahead with its third-quarter report last week.On a conference call with analysts, Target CEO Brian Cornell said the retailer saw "a meaningful improvement in sales of Apple products, driven by their introduction of several new product innovations" last quarter.Mark Tritton, Target's chief merchandising officer, sees the Apple momentum continuing this quarter."In electronics this quarter, we're planning for strong demand for Apple's new products," he said on the call. "We're also expecting a lot of guest interest in virtual reality, along with connected home devices like Google Home."Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google Home is a smart speaker that answers spoken questions and plays music on command. It competes with Amazon.com's (AMZN) market-leading Echo devices.Consumer Intelligence Research Partners on Monday estimated that Amazon has sold 5.1 million Echo devices in the U.S. since the product debuted in late 2014. In the first nine months of 2016, it sold about 2 million Echo appliances, CIRP said.RELATED:Wireless Headphones, 4K TVs, Drones Top Christmas Wish Lists

Citigroup started American Airlines (AAL), Delta Air Lines (DAL), and Southwest Airlines (LUV) with buy ratings; Salesforce.com's (CRM) higher-than-expected revenue guidance won the cloud software provider price target hikes; and Raymond James upgraded Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) to outperform.Citigroup initiated American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, Southwest Airlines and Allegiant Travel at buy. Citigroup analyst set a price target of 55 on American, 61 on Delta, 57 on Southwest and 185 on Allegiant."Key fundamentals are mixed with expenses likely to be up sharply in 2017 as fuel prices drift higher and new labor deals pressure nonfuel unit costs," said Crissey in a report. "The stocks appear reasonably priced to cheap, both in a historical context and relative to the market."Citigroup also started JetBlue Airways (JBLU), Spirit (SAV), Alaska Air Group (ALK), Hawaiian  Holdings (HA), and United Continental (UAL) all at neutral.American stock edged up 0.9% to 46.26 on stock market today. Delta rose 0.8% to 48.90. American, Delta, United and Southwest had big weekly gains after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) disclosed stakes in the carriers.RELATED:Warren Buffett, Who Called Airline Stocks A 'Death Trap,' Invests In Big 4Delta October Unit Revenue In Line, Alaska Air Traffic Outpaces CapacitySouthwest Is Only Airline That Sees Worse Unit Revenue; Stock DivesJetBlue Warns On Q4, Spirit Sees Improving Unit RevenueWedbush hiked its price target on Salesforce.com to 98 from 96, Mizuho Securities to 95 from 85, and BMO Capital Markets to 90 from 86. Salesforce.com late Thursday reported fiscal Q3 earnings and revenue that topped views and also forecast current-quarter and fiscal 2018 revenue above expectations. San Francisco-based Salesforce.com said in fiscal 2018 it expects revenue of about $10.1 billion-$10.15 billion, up 21% at the midpoint, vs. consensus estimates of $10.08 billion."Most importantly, reported billings grew 19% (year-over-year), and we calculate that organic (credit card) billings grew by about 21%," said Keith Bachman, a BMO Capital analyst in a report.Shares rose 3.4% to 77.77 Friday.RELATED:Salesforce.com Fiscal Q3 Beats, Sales Guidance Top Views, Shares UpSalesforce.com M&A Scorecard Raises Questions On Growth, TargetsSalesforce.com Officially Rules Out Twitter BidPacific Crest Securities upped its price target on Applied Materials, a maker of semiconductor manufacturing gear, to 37 from 35; Citigroup bumped up its price target to 38 from 37. Applied Materials late Thursday delivered mixed fiscal Q4 results but gave current-quarter guidance ahead of Wall Street's views. Applied materials stock has popped 64% in 2016. The company has an IBD Composite Rating of 98 out of a possible 99.Applied Materials stock rose 1 cent to 30.74. Intraday, shares rose to 31.25, a 16-year high and briefly above a 31.17 buy point.RELATED:Applied Materials Earnings Soar, Guidance Strong, But Sales Just MissApplied Materials Makes 'Compelling Case' For Growth In Chip Gear SectorRaymond James upgraded Hewlett Packard Enterprise, which reports fiscal Q4 earnings on Nov. 22, to outperform. Analyst Simon Leopold set a price target of 29 on HPE stock. With HPE's planned spin off its enterprise services and software businesses, he expects improved free cash flow growth.Shares dipped 1.2% to 23.31. Shares rose to 23.85 intraday, briefly crossing 23.63 buy point.RELATED:Could HPE Go Shopping For Cisco Rival Arista Networks?In other analyst moves, Macquarie Securities downgraded Citigroup (C) to neutral; Raymond James hiked its price target on Best Buy (BBY) to 53 from 45;  RBC Capital lowered its price target on Wal-Mart Stores (WMT)  to 42 from 47. Jefferies hiked its price target on chipmaker Marvell Technology (MRVL) to 18 from 16. BTIG Research upped its price target on Dish Network (DISH) to 90 from 85. Aegis Capital started Match Group (MTCH) with a buy rating and a price target of 20.

U.S. stock indexes poked higher in mixed volume, after Fed chief Janet Yellen gave a clear indication of a rate hike "relatively soon" and vowed to serve a full term.The Nasdaq advanced 0.7%, while the S&P 500 rose 0.4%. The blue chip Dow Jones industrial average added 0.1%. Volume in the stock market today was running lower on the NYSE and higher on the Nasdaq.Yellen's term runs through January 2018. President-elect Donald Trump has talked both ways on Yellen. In May, he said he had "great respect" for Yellen. In September, he said Yellen is "very political" and "she should be ashamed of herself."Meanwhile, CME Group's FedWatch Tool pegs the chance for a December rate hike at 90.6%, unchanged from the previous day.Banks are expected to benefit from higher rates, and the bank stocks continued to show strength Thursday. The KBW Nasdaq Bank Index popped 1.6%. PowerShares KBW Bank Portfolio (KBWB), the exchange-traded fund that tracks the index, has risen almost 14% since the market's Election Day close. The ETF has 24 bank stocks in its portfolio with Bank of America (BAC) its biggest holding at 8.4%.In the S&P 500, Best Buy (BBY) was the day's best performer, up 11% in huge volume. The stock broke out Wednesday, clearing a 40.31 buy point. The consumer electronics retailer trounced the Street's views on earnings by 32%, according to William O'Neil + Co. data. Same-store sales also were stronger than expected.Among IBD's 197 industry groups, the homebuilder group was headed for a seventh consecutive daily gain. October housing starts came in strong, topping the consensus view by 13% and surpassing the highest estimate in the range by 9%.RELATED:Yellen Here To Stay; Rate Hike Coming 'Relatively Soon'Which Rebounded More, Stocks Or Home Prices?
