Microsoft (MSFT) on Wednesday continued its foray into PC hardware by introducing an all-in-one desktop PC to go with its Surface notebook line.The Redmond, Wash.-based software leader also announced the next version of its Windows PC operating system, Windows 10 Creators Update, which will be available early next year.Microsoft unveiled the new products at an event in New York City.Microsoft stock fell a fraction to 60.63 on the stock market today. Microsoft shares hit an all-time high of 61.37 on Tuesday, three trading days after the company beat Wall Street's targets for revenue and earnings per share in the September quarter.IBD'S TAKE: Microsoft stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 79, meaning it has outperformed 79% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. For more details on Microsoft, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.The new desktop PC, called Surface Studio, features a 28-inch ultra-high-resolution touch-screen display with a hinge that lets the screen adjust from desktop to studio mode. In studio mode, the screen lies at a 20-degree angle, like a standard drafting board, for sketching, writing and designing with a finger or the Surface Pen stylus.Another method of input is the Surface Dial, a new peripheral that lets people use two hands on the screen to compose and create in new ways. The Surface Dial was designed for the creative process, Microsoft said. The $99 peripheral integrates with Windows 10 and Surface for a faster and more intuitive way to scroll, zoom and navigate.Microsoft described Surface Studio as a new class of computing device that transforms from a workstation into a digital canvas.Surface Studio runs sixth-generation Intel (INTC) Core processors accelerated by a discrete Nvidia (NVDA) GeForce graphics processing unit.The Surface Studio starts at $2,999 and is available for preorder now through Microsoft retail stores and MicrosoftStore.com and Best Buy's (BBY) online store. It will ship in limited quantities this holiday season with broader availability in early 2017.Microsoft also released new models of its Surface notebooks. It introduced Surface Book with Performance Base, which features faster processors, more graphics power and better battery life. Surface Book with Performance Base starts at $2,399, is available for preorder now and will be out Nov. 10.Microsoft's latest Windows 10 software release is aimed at artists, graphic designers and other creators.Launching as a free download in early 2017, the Windows 10 Creators Update will let people create and share 3D graphics; experience virtual and augmented reality with low-cost headsets; and empower PC gamers to be online broadcasters.The Windows 10 update will feature Paint 3D, a version of Microsoft Paint for 3D art creation. Microsoft also has opened a new online community, Remix3D.com, for artists to share their works.Plus, Microsoft has partnered with Trimble (TRMB) to bring its 3D modeling program SketchUp to Remix3D.com.RELATED:Adobe, Microsoft Hit New Highs On Cloud ProspectsMicrosoft Beats September Quarter Sales, EPS Targets

Tech names Alibaba (BABA), Facebook (FB), Best Buy (BBY), Texas Instruments (TXN) and Broadcom (AVGO) lead your stocks to watch this week, with the Chinese e-commerce giant and social media leader providing buying opportunities and the rest nearing buy points.Alibaba, a member of IBD's Leaderboard, entered a follow-on buy zone after finding support at its 50-day moving average near the 100 price level, marking the first buying opportunity since its August breakout.Fellow Leaderboard member Domino's Pizza (DPZ) recently presented a similar buy zone with a bounce from the 50-day before zooming higher on earnings.Facebook, another Leaderboard member, is trading back in buy range from an entry at 128.43 after finding support at its 50-day line. The stock topped its all-time high of 131.98 and closed Friday just a penny below a secondary buy point of 132.08.Ahead of the holiday shopping season, big-box consumer-electronics retailer Best Buy is 2% below a 40.31 buy point as it works on the handle of a cup-with-handle base.Texas Instruments found support at the 50-day line and is 3.8% below a potential buy point at 72.68, ahead of its quarterly earnings on Wednesday. Chip peer Broadcom also got support at its 50-day and is 3.7% below a 179.52 buy point.

The overall 0.6% bounceback in retail sales last month comes with a caveat: Total spending looked healthy, but much of the gain came in categories that may not drive growth going forward.A core measure of goods spending that strips out restaurants, cars and gas, as well as building materials, rose just 0.1% in September. That was well below the 0.4% gain expected by economists and came after a 0.1% decline in this broad "control group" category of retail spending.Sales at electronics and appliance stores like Best Buy (BBY) remained a sore spot. Despite the midmonth launch of the Apple (AAPL) iPhone 7, seasonally adjusted sales fell 0.9% from August and 3.8% from a year ago. Best Buy shares fell 1.3% on the stock market today but are still near 52-week highs. Apple is near 2016 highs amid strong initial iPhone 7 demand and rival Samsung's overheating problems with its Note 7, which finally prompted the company to end sales and production of the smartphone.Slumping demand for PCs and printers led Hewlett-Packard (HP) on Thursday to announce a gradual reduction of 3,000 to 4,000 jobs. Electronics retailers also are being squeezed by the likes of Amazon (AMZN). Nonstore retailers saw September sales rise 0.3% from August after a 0.1% dip the prior month. Though online sales momentum has cooled a bit in the past few months, nonstore retailers still are posting double-digit year-over-year gains — 10.6% in September.Department store sales slid 0.7% from August and 6.4% from a year ago. Some of the slide reflects store closures. Still, analysts at Sterne Agee downgraded shares of Macy's (M) to neutral from buy on Friday, noting a slowdown in same-store sales growth. JPMorgan cut price targets and Q3 estimates on Macy's, JCPenney (JCP), Kohl's (KSS), Nordstrom (JWN) and Dillard's (DDS).Macy's, Kohl's shares fell about 3% Friday while Dillard's skidded 4.6%. Kohl's and Nordstom fell fractionally.Everything to do with the housing market shined in September. Sales at building materials and garden equipment stores like Home Depot (HD) surged 1.4% from August, more than reversing a 0.8% decline the prior month. Meanwhile, furniture store sales rose 1.0% from August and 2.7% from a year ago.Home Depot shares rose 0.1%.One of the surprises in the retail report was the strong gain in spending at food service and drinking places, up 0.8% from August, when sales rose 0.7%. Sales have moderated on a year-over-year basis to 6.1% from the 8%-plus pace that prevailed for most of 2015. Still, the gains over the past two months are a pleasant surprise given that McDonald's (MCD), Wendy's (WEN), Jack in the Box (JACK) and others have cited pressure from the growing cost gap between eating in and eating out.McDonald's stock fell 1.1%, while Wendy's and Jack in the Box rose fractionally.IBD'S TAKE: The Retail-Restaurants industry group is ranked in the lower tier by IBD, No. 113 out of 197 based on share performance. Investors will generally have more success buying leaders in top-tier groups, when the market trend is favorable. Sill, Papa Johns and Dunkin' Brands, are close to buy points and worth watching. Go to IBD Stock Checkup to find out why they're the two top stocks in the group.September restaurant sales data out Thursday from TDn2K covering 25,000 locations shed further light on industry trends. Overall, same-store sales fell 1.1% from a year ago in September, while customer traffic slumped 3.5%. The sector is on pace for its worst performance since 2009.Still, overall sales are performing better than same-store sales because of continued industry expansion, and the quick-service industry is doing a whole lot better than the rest, growing same-store sales 2.2% from a year ago in the third quarter, Nation's Restaurant News reported.On Friday, Bank of America analysts upgraded Domino's Pizza (DPZ) to buy from underperform, noting that the research firm expects 10.4% U.S. same-store sales growth in the third quarter. Domino's reports on Tuesday before the open. Domino's rose 0.5%.Auto sales jumped 1.1% in September, as U.S. vehicle sales rose to a 17.76 million annual rate from 17 million the prior month. Sales of higher-margin pickups and SUVs outperformed at Ford (F), General Motors (GM) and Fiat Chrysler (FCAU), helping offset their unit sales declines vs. a year ago."The decline in gasoline prices relative to a year ago is likely to continue to support SUV sales," wrote Jefferies economists Ward McCarthy and Thomas Simons. "Nonetheless, overall vehicle sales are at a level that may be close to a ceiling."Ford shares closed unchanged. GM rallied 1.1% and Fiat Chrysler shares 2.3%.Gas station sales helped pump up the overall retail sales gain, rising 2.4% from August. McCarthy and Simons noted that the big rise was based on seasonal adjustments: Gas prices fell in 0.8% in September, but they usually fall 2.8% during the month after the peak summer driving season.RELATED:Off The Charts: Fast Food Inflation Vs. Eating InU.S. Auto Sales Sluggish, But Top Views On Strong Truck Demand

Retail sales rose 0.6% in September, despite not much help from launch of the Apple (AAPL) iPhone 7, the Commerce Department reported Friday.Sales hit the consensus forecast of a 0.6% rise overall and a 0.5% gain outside the auto sector.Last month's report, which showed that nonauto sales fell 0.1% in August, was revised to a 0.2% decline.After consumer spending slowed over the summer, a healthy recovery isn't expected to affect the Federal Reserve's timetable for rate hikes — one in December and two next year.The retail sales report reflected and shed light on evolving industry dynamics.Auto sales hit the gas in September, rising to a 17.76 million annual rate from 17 million the prior month. While unit sales dropped from a year ago at Ford (F), General Motors (GM) and Fiat Chrysler (FCAU), sales of higher-margin pickups and SUVs performed relatively well.Sales from nonstore retailers led by Amazon (AMZN) rose 0.3% from August and 10.6% from a year ago following a rare 0.1% drop the prior month that was possibly an aftereffect of Amazon Prime Day in July.IBD'S TAKE: Health and personal care retailers have seen 7.8% year-over-year sales growth, strongest outside of nonstore retailers. Ulta Beauty, an IBD 50 stock, boosted sales and earnings forecasts on Thursday and saw its shares surge above a seven-week consolidation zone.Sales at electronics and appliance stores such as Best Buy (BBY) fell 0.9% despite the iPhone launch in mid-September. Best Buy shares are trading near 52-week highs. Apple is near 2016 highs after strong initial iPhone 7 demand and again this month as Samsung faced repeated overheating problems with its Note 7, finally deciding to end sales and production of the smartphone.Sales at food service and drinking places had been decelerating, as fast-food chains like McDonald's (MCD) cite pressure from the growing cost gap between eating in and eating out. But sector sales rose 0.8% in September after a revised gain of 0.7% in August.RELATED:U.S. Auto Sales Sluggish, But Top Views On Strong Truck DemandAugust Retail Sales Fall 0.3%, Worse Than Expected

Sony's (SNE) entry into the virtual reality market became a reality Thursday with the launch of its PlayStation VR system for the PlayStation 4 video game console.While the official launch was Thursday, retailers Best Buy (BBY) and GameStop (GME) held evening launch events Wednesday at many stores in the U.S.IBD'S TAKE: Sony stock has a below-average IBD Composite Rating of 46, meaning it has been outperformed by 54% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. Sony is ranked No. 5 out of 10 stocks in IBD's Consumer Products-Electronic industry group. The top stock in the group is Universal Electronics. For more information, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.PlayStation VR launched with a lineup of 30 games, including exclusives like "Batman: Arkham VR" from RockSteady and Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment, "DriveClub VR" and "RIGS Mechanized Combat League" from SIE Worldwide Studios, and "Rez Infinite" from Monstars & Enhance Games. Sony expects to have about 50 VR games available by year-end.Sony's VR system is cheaper than PC-connected headsets offered by Facebook's (FB) Oculus and HTC. Sony's headset costs $400 compared with $600 for Oculus Rift and $800 for HTC Vive.Sony has a leg up on its rivals because the PS VR is compatible with the more than 40 million PS4 systems already in consumers' homes. The Oculus and HTC systems require high-end personal computers, which aren't as prevalent."We believe PS VR has the power to make VR gaming a reality for the mainstream, and the impact that PS VR will have on the future of both games and entertainment will be transformative," Shawn Layden, president of Sony Interactive Entertainment America and chairman of SIE Worldwide Studios, said in a statement.Virtual reality systems are designed to make players feel like they are inside the world of a video game by using surround video and audio.Sony's U.S. shares finished 1.7% higher at 33.27 on the stock market today.Upcoming games for the Sony PS VR include "Resident Evil 7: Biohazard" from Capcom, "Star Wars Battlefront: Rogue One X-wing VR Mission" from Electronic Arts (EA), and "Star Trek: Bridge Crew" from Ubisoft.Last week, research firm IHS Markit predicted that Sony will sell 1.4 million PlayStation VR headsets this year, but will be supply constrained.Video game market research firm SuperData Research forecasts that Sony will sell 2.6 million PS VR units by year-end.RELATED:Virtual-Reality Headset Sales To Soar With Sony PlayStation VR Launch

The launch next week of Sony's (SNE) PlayStation VR system is going to give the fledgling virtual-reality headset market a shot of adrenaline.Research firm IHS Technology predicted Thursday that PlayStation VR will outsell HTC Vive and Facebook's (FB) Oculus Rift combined in 2016, but also will be supply-constrained as the company plays it safe on stock inventory.PlayStation VR works with Sony's market-leading PlayStation 4 video game console, so it has an established market to sell into. By contrast, HTC Vive and Oculus Rift require users to own a high-end PC.Sony will begin selling PlayStation VR on Oct. 13. The headset costs $400. A bundle with the headset, two PlayStation Move motion controllers, a PlayStation camera and PlayStation VR Worlds game disc costs $500.IBD'S TAKE: Sony could use another hit product. Sony stock has a middling IBD Composite Rating of 45. It ranks No. 7 out of 10 companies in IBD's Consumer Products-Electronic industry group. To see which company leads the group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Consumer electronics retailer Best Buy (BBY) is holding launch events at about 350 stores nationwide. Stores will sell PlayStation VR starting at 12:01 a.m. ET next Thursday, 9:01 p.m. Wednesday PT.The installed base of PS4 consoles is expected to reach 53 million by year-end, compared with 16 million VR-ready consumer PCs, IHS said. PlayStation VR also is cheaper than Oculus Rift, which costs $600 for the headset alone.IHS forecasts that Sony will sell 1.4 million PlayStation VR headsets this year and will generate $134 million in spending on VR entertainment content. IHS predicts that PC-based headsets will generate $69 million in spending on VR entertainment this year."Sony is well-positioned to build an early lead in the high-end VR headset race because of its large addressable market of 53 million PS4s by the end of 2016, its lower total cost of ownership compared to the PC VR companies and its ability to get big franchises into VR," IHS analyst Piers Harding-Rolls said in a statement. "With VR content and users strongly aligned with the games market, Sony already has in place many of the components necessary to deliver to this new VR entertainment segment at the expense of its competitors."U.S.-traded shares of Sony fell a fraction to 32.72 on the stock market today. On Sept. 22, Sony stock touched its highest price since March 2011, at 34.17.Meanwhile, low-end VR headsets that use smartphones for their displays will be major unit-volume drivers in the VR market.Aggressive promotional activity from smartphone vendors and new smartphone VR systems, such as Google's Daydream View, will push the total installed base of VR headsets from 4 million units last year to 81 million in 2020, IHS said.Consumer spending on VR headsets will be $1.6 billion in 2016, bolstered heavily by the launch of high-end headsets from Oculus, HTC and Sony. In 2020, consumer spending on VR headsets will reach $7.9 billion, IHS predicted.Spending on VR games and videos is seen rising from $310 million in 2016 to $3.3 billion in 2020, IHS said. High-end VR systems will sell the most content, the firm said."There will be a polarization of the VR market between lower-volume premium VR headsets, which will have strong paid-content conversion rates, and higher-volume cheaper smartphone VR headsets, which will monetize content at a lower rate," Harding-Rolls said.Smartphone VR headsets will make up 87% of the VR installed base by year's end, the research firm said.Samsung's Gear VR is the biggest product in the smartphone-based VR market today. Alphabet (GOOGL) expects to make a splash with its Daydream View, which will be available for preorder on Oct. 20 for $79. The Daydream was among the hardware products Alphabet unveiled Tuesday.IHS forecasts Samsung's Gear VR to have the largest installed base out of all the major branded headsets in 2016 with 5.4 million units. Google's Daydream View, however, will slowly disrupt Samsung's dominant position in the smartphone-VR market, it said.RELATED:Review: Sony delivers worthy virtual-reality experienceBatman, 'Battlezone' and brainteasers lead Sony VR lineupFacebook, Sony Lead Virtual Reality Stock Picks In Nomura Report

U.S. stock indexes suffered routine losses Friday afternoon as the market neared its final hour of trade.The Nasdaq slouched 0.2%, while the S&P 500 matched that loss. The blue chip Dow Jones industrial average was flat, but the small cap Russell 2000 dropped 0.7%. Volume in the stock market today was running slightly higher on the NYSE and slightly lower on the Nasdaq.The Dow Jones utility average delivered one of the day's better gains, up 0.6%. A weaker than expected payrolls report might have helped the dividend-paying utilities, but the utilities were also due for some kind of rebound.Consolidated Edison (ED) had dropped 10 sessions in a row, making Friday's gain a trivial triumph. Southern Co. (SO) fell nine sessions in a row, and it too rose Friday. The two utilities rose about 2% and 1% respectively but then reversed to nominal gains.Among IBD's 197 industry groups, five of the day's nine top gainers were from retail or the related apparel makers groups.Gap (GPS), the owner of the namesake and Old Navy chains, thrust 15% as it retook its 200-day and 50-day lines in huge volume. September sales were a bit more than expected. Francesca's (FRAN), another retailer in the same apparel/shoes group, popped 2%. The stock cleared a 16.30 buy point in an awkward pattern. Volume was below average.Other retailers doing well included department store Nordstrom (JWN), which added to Thursday's breakout; Best Buy (BBY), which climbed closer to an entry in a flat base; apparel maker PVH Corp. (PVH), which padded a recent breakout; and big box retailer PriceSmart (PSMT), which advanced 3% as it tries to build the right side of a pattern.On the downside, the day's worst performer was Food-Meat Products. Allegations that the poultry industry conspired since 2007 to fix prices rattled the group. Tyson Foods (TSN) dropped 9%; Sanderson Farms (SAFM), 6%; and Pilgrim's Pride (PPC), 5%.RELATEDU.S. Added Just 156,000 Jobs In September; Won't Change FedOil Rig Count Rises, But Texas Plays See Dips

Action-camera maker GoPro (GPRO) is set to unveil its Karma drone on Monday, but many observers are wondering if the company will price itself out of the fast-growing market.Karma is expected to cost more than $500 without a camera, bringing the price of a GoPro flying-camera system to $900 to $1,000, Dougherty analyst Charles Anderson said in a research report Tuesday. Karma will debut at a time when the growth driver for the market is expected to be drones with 4K cameras costing $500 or less, he said.IBD'S TAKE: GoPro stock carries a poor IBD Composite Rating of 12, meaning it has been outperformed by 88% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. It ranks No. 10 out of 11 companies in IBD's Computer Products-Electronic industry group. To see which company leads the group, check out the IBD Stock Checkup.At last week's InterDrone trade show in Las Vegas, industry officials were mixed on GoPro's prospects in the drone market, Anderson said."Some in the industry felt as though GoPro would not be competitive with the likes of the Yuneec Breeze and the DJI Mavic given an expectation that the Karma will be $500-plus without an attached camera," Anderson said in the report. "Others felt as though GoPro's brand, distribution and installed base of drone-ready cameras would be enough to give it a strong initial ramp."A major trend at InterDrone 2016 was the emergence of the sub-$500 consumer drone with 4K video, Anderson said.Yuneec showed off its $499 Breeze drone, which is controlled by a smartphone app as opposed to an expensive joystick common in the industry."The Breeze struck us as the most consumer-friendly drone we've ever seen and includes multiple semiautonomous modes including 'follow me' and 'selfie mode' — whereby users set a certain height and distance from the themselves and the drone levitates on its own," Anderson said.Market leader DJI is expected to debut its low-cost Mavic drone this month.Yuneec is going to get as much as 10 feet of shelf space for its products at Best Buy (BBY) this holiday and the drone category will get nearly 30 feet total at Best Buy stores, Anderson said.Also at the InterDrone show, video processor maker Ambarella (AMBA) continued to be the industry standard on 4K drones, with Qualcomm (QCOM) lagging far behind, Anderson said.Dougherty rates GoPro and Ambarella stocks as neutral. GoPro stock rose 2.1%, to 13.07, in the stock market today. Shares hit a seven-month high of 16.25 on Aug. 15. Ambarella stock was up 2.4% to 67.43. Shares touched a nearly one-year high just shy of 73 on Aug. 31.GoPro may use its Karma unveiling to also launch its Hero 5 action camera and possibly a handheld gimbal accessory, Oppenheimer analyst Andrew Uerkwitz said in a report Tuesday.He rates GoPro stock as perform and expects the company's products to face a lot of competition for consumer spending this holiday season. GoPro's cameras and drones will compete not only with similar products, but also with virtual-reality headsets, wearables, video game consoles and new smartphones.RELATED:Why The Next Apple Could Come From A Drone WildcatterWhat It's Like To Quit Your Job To Be A Competitive Drone RacerWhat's Next For Drones? Expect Some Fireworks, LiterallyApple iPhone 7 Camera Improvements Rile GoPro

The second tech "unicorn" this year, following Twilio (TWLO), is galloping to the starting gate for its initial public offering.Nutanix looks to raise $196 million by offering 14 million shares at a price range of 13 to 15 each. That's up from its previous range of 11 to 13, suggesting strong interest from big investors.That translates to a market valuation of about $1.7 billion, which is below the $2 billion valuation placed on the company from a 2014 funding round that gave it unicorn status. Unicorn is a term used for privately held companies with a valuation of at least $1 billion.The biggest unicorns, such as Uber and Snapchat, get the most buzz, but Nutanix also has received a fair amount of attention. The company pioneered a field called hyperconvergence infrastructure, a market that research firm IDC estimates could reach $5 billion in 2019, up from $2 billion this year.Nutanix provides an enterprise cloud platform that converges traditional silos of servers, virtualization software and storage into one integrated solution. It's designed to reduce complexity and lower costs.Nutanix is slated to price late Thursday and begin trading on the Nasdaq Friday morning under the ticker NTNX.The IPO market, after a slow first half of the year, began to gain speed with the May 13 IPO of Acacia Communications (ACIA), which popped 35% on its first trading day. Acacia, a provider of high-speed fiber-optic communications gear, priced at 23.The stock closed down 0.5% at 102.98 on the stock market Thursday.Acacia was followed by cloud software provider Twilio on June 23, which jumped 92% on the first day of trading. It priced at 15 and finished 0.4% lower Thursday at 68.72.Japan-based messaging service Line (LN), up 50% from its IPO price of 32.75, has been another solid IPO. Line shares dipped 0.6% to 49.02.Other strong-performing IPOs include Impinj (PI), a provider of radio-frequency identification tags and reader chips, and Talend (TLND), a Big Data and cloud integration software maker. An investment bank recently initiated Talend coverage with a buy rating.IBD'S TAKE: IPOs are a wellspring of innovation and can be huge stock winners. But they can reverse quickly. Read this IPO Analysis: IPO leaders Can Fall Hardest In A Weak Market. It's important to focus on younger companies that are on the rise and doing new things, so IBD focuses on companies that went public within the past three years in the IPO Leaders column. IBD can also help you understand strong IPO bases.Nutanix said it has 3,768 customers as of July 31, up from 782 customers two years ago. Customers include Activision Blizzard (ATVI), Best Buy (BBY), Kellogg (K) and Nintendo (NTDOY), according to its IPO prospectus.San Jose, Calif.-based Nutanix has been growing fast but also shows large losses as it invests big sums on sales and marketing and research and development.For the 12-month period ended July 31, Nutanix reported revenue of $445 million, up 84% from the year-earlier period, and a net loss of $168.5 million.For the quarter ended July 31, Nutanix reported revenue of $139.8 million, up 89%, and a net loss of $50 million.Competitors include Dell, which recently acquired data storage systems company EMC, in the process picking up EMC-majority-owned VMware (VMW), a leading provider of virtualization software. Competitors also include Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) and Cisco Systems (CSCO).RELATED: The 'Amazing' IPO Change That May Restart The Flow Of New StocksEverbridge Soars In Debut After Acacia, Twilio, Line IPOs BoomAcacia, Twilio, Line IPOs Prime Market For Post-Labor Day Pickup

Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen said the case for a rate hike is stronger now, but investors weren't sure what to make of that. Pfizer (PFE) paid $14 billion for a one-drug biotech, but shares of drugs and pharma supply chain companies sold off as Mylan's (MYL) EpiPen price hikes drew outrage. Best Buy (BBY) earnings surprised investors, while dollar stores came under pressure.For the week, the Nasdaq fell 0.4%, the S&P 500 0.7% and the Dow 0.8%. The major averages are still in sideways action. Drug stocks were big movers on Pfizer's Medivation (MDVN) deal and Mylan's EpiPen furor. Dollar stores suffered heavy losses as competition from Wal-Mart (WMT) was heating up.Fed Chair Janet Yellen said at Friday's long-awaited speech that the case for an interest rate hike has "strengthened in recent months." That followed other modestly hawkish statements from fellow Fed policymakers. However, Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer said Yellen's comments were consistent with a September rate increase. He saw the possibility of two rate hikes this year. Markets had already priced a Fed move, perhaps in December, but they don't expect any quick follow-upNew-home sales soared to a 654,000 annual rate in July, by far the highest since October 2007, the Commerce Department reported. The 12% rise from June surprised economists looking for a slight dip to 580,000. Luxury homebuilder Toll Bros. (TOL) confirmed that the high end of the market is prospering, reporting a 69% jump in third-quarter earnings per share, a 23.5% rise in revenue and a strong backlog of orders. Existing-home sales fell more than expected in July, though that was from June's cycle high. But applications for loans to buy a home fell to a six-month low. Toll shares soared to a seven-month high, moving above their 200-day moving average.The generic drugmaker Mylan sold off 11.55% for the week as members of the Senate and other politicians started inquiring into its price increases on its emergency allergy drug/device EpiPen. That fueled selling in drug and biotech stocks. Mylan CEO Heather Bresch, daughter of Sen. Joe Machin, D-W.V., said only a fraction of the $608 list price makes it back to Mylan, due to all the middlemen, leading shares of Express Scripts (ESRX), CVS Health (CVS) and AmerisourceBergen (ABC) to fall as well.Big pharma Pfizer agreed to buy Medivation for $14 billion in cash, snatching the cancer-drug specialist from Sanofi (SNY), which had been trying for months to acquire Medivation. Biotechs rallied Monday on the news, with BioMarin Pharmaceutical (BMRN) jumping on rumors that it was Sanofi's second choice of target. On Wednesday, Pfizer agreed to buy the antibiotics business of AstraZeneca (AZN) for $725 million plus possible future milestone and sales payments and royalties that could amount to $850 million.Oil prices may be settling into a trading range in the mid to high $40 range. OPEC members gave conflicting signals over whether they might support a production freeze, while Goldman Sachs said such a move would not "be sufficient to support prices much further." Meanwhile, the Energy Information Administration said U.S. crude inventories rose by 2.5 million barrels vs. expectations for a small drop. Domestic production fell slightly.The road to self-driving cars got a little more crowded as Mobileye (MBLY) announced it will partner with General Motors (GM) supplier Delphi Automotive (DLPH) to jointly develop off-the-shelf autonomous driving technology for automakers. The two companies will co-develop "the market's first turnkey Level 4/5 automated driving solution." Mobileye already has deal with BMW (BMWYY) and Intel (INTC) to bring an autonomous vehicle to market by 2021.Mobileye shares spiked Tuesday on the Delphi news, briefly topping a buy point. Shares rose 2.3% for the week.Tesla Motors (TSLA), which is ending its business relationship with Mobileye, introduced new versions of its Model S and X that boosts speeds and driving range, powered by an updated battery technology. Tesla said its upgraded Model S is now the fastest-accelerating car in commercial production. Tesla shares fell 2.2%, closing below the 50-day line and just above the 200-day line.Tesla partner Nvidia (NVDA) unveiled a new processor for autonomous driving, saying it's 50%-100% more powerful than other mobile processors.The beauty products retailer reported better-than-expected earnings and sales, with yet another quarter of double-digit same-stores growth. Ulta Beauty (ULTA) also raised full-year EPS guidance. But its Q3 profit range was a little cautious. Ulta shares have been on a strong run-up, so it may have been priced for perfection. Ulta shares tumbled 6% on Friday, undercutting its 50-day moving average.Workday (WDAY) reported a wider-than-expected Q2 adjusted loss. But it topped on some key metrics, including revenue, which rose 34% to $377.7 million. But shares of the cloud-based human resources software maker rose 2.5%, hitting a 2016 high on Thursday.July IPO Talend (TLND) lost an adjusted $1.84 a share, according to its late Thursday release, but the French Big Data firm later clarified that the bottom line actually met estimates for a loss of 31 cents a share after adjusting for the share count following its initial offering. Revenue rose 38% to $25.4 million, just beating. Talend sees Q3 losses in line with views, but it guided revenue slightly higher. Shares fell 4% after much bigger intraday losses.Best Buy (BBY) stock jumped 21% for the week to a 17-month high on better-than-expected sales and earnings for its fiscal second quarter, including a surprise increase in same-store sales. The consumer electronics retailer credited rising demand for wearable technology, appliances and home-theater systems for the increase. Video game and electronics retailer GameStop (GME) disappointed investors with in-line EPS and below-forecast sales.Discount retailers Dollar General (DG) and Dollar Tree (DLTR) suffered double-digit share price losses, as both reported second-quarter results that came up short of Wall Street expectations, with falling grocery prices and tougher competition hurting sales. Those results came as Wal-Mart is waging its own campaign to cut prices, a move that could draw more customers who have become more cautious with their spending.Meanwhile, the jeweler Tiffany (TIF) held to its full-year outlook, while its Q2 EPS beat views, helping to boost shares. However, Signet Jewelers (SIG), the parent of mall jewelers Kay, Jared and Zales, slashed its fiscal-year outlook, partly due to difficulties "in the energy-dependent regions." Those regions' economies have been hurt by cheap oil and other commodities.HP Inc. (HPQ) reported that its fiscal Q3 earnings per share minus one-time items jumped 37% in fiscal Q3 to 48 cents on a 4% decline in sales to $11.89 billion, both better than views. For the current quarter, the printer and PC maker sees non-GAAP EPS of 34-37 cents, vs. consensus for 41 cents. HP is reducing its printing supplies inventory and is deeply discounting printers to expand its installed base. Shares closed little changed after a brief Thursday morning sell-off.

Investors "rage quit" on GameStop (GME) on Friday after the video game retailer reported weaker-than-expected sales in its fiscal second quarter.GameStop stock fell 10.6% to 28.74 on the stock market today.Late Thursday, the Grapevine, Texas-based company said it earned 27 cents a share, down 13% year over year but in line with estimates, for its fiscal Q2 ended July 30. However, sales fell 7% to $1.63 billion during a weak quarter for the video game industry. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were modeling for sales of $1.72 billion, down 2%.Same-store sales dropped 10.6% in Q2, GameStop said.On the plus side, GameStop executives reiterated their earnings guidance for the full year and guided EPS higher for the current quarter.For fiscal Q3, GameStop expects earnings per share of 53 to 58 cents, when analysts were targeting 53 cents. For fiscal 2016, which ends on Jan. 28, GameStop is forecasting EPS of $3.90 to $4.05. At the midpoint of its guidance, EPS would be up 2% year over year.GameStop's results are in contrast to consumer electronics retailer Best Buy (BBY), which earlier in the week reported a same-store sales increase and better-than-expected results for its July quarter.IBD'S TAKE: GameStop has an IBD Composite Rating of 34, meaning it has been outperformed by 66% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. For a list of top stocks, check out the IBD 50.GameStop's new businesses and upcoming hardware and software launches make the stock more of a second-half 2016 and 2017 story, Wedbush Securities analyst Michael Pachter said in a report Friday.Pachter reiterated his outperform rating on GameStop with a 12-month price target of 36.On the negative side, GameStop lowered its full-year sales guidance despite big product launches, such as new game consoles from Microsoft (MSFT) and Sony (SNE) and the Sony PlayStation VR virtual reality headset launch.GameStop sees sales in a range of down 2% to up 1.5%, vs. previous guidance for flat to up 3%, Pachter said.GameStop has been diversifying from video game shops to stores dedicated to selling Apple (AAPL) products, pop-culture collectibles, and devices and services for AT&T (T).Oppenheimer analyst Brian Nagel reiterated his perform rating on GameStop stock."Management continues to successfully  diversify  its  revenue  and  profit  streams  into  new  categories  and  away from the legacy physical gaming business," Nagel said in a report. "But, once again, physical gaming proved much weaker than guidance and the expectations of investors. We applaud GameStop for having the foresight to seek new directions for its model. That said, bears remain in control of the GME story."Baird analyst Colin Sebastian maintained his outperform rating on GameStop, but lowered his price target to 40 from 42.GameStop's video game sales have been pressured by the shift to digital downloads and difficult year-over-year comparisons for hardware and software sales.Bright spots in GameStop's Q2 report were mobile and consumer electronics sales up 43% to $203 million and collectibles sales up 120% to $90 million. Pokemon collectibles were a big seller last quarter thanks to the popularity of the "Pokemon Go" smartphone game, GameStop Chief Operating Officer Tony Bartel told IBD."Our transformation is in full swing," Bartel said. In Q2, GameStop had more than 50% of its profit coming from nonphysical video games. About 29% of the company's sales are now from nongames businesses, including its technology brands.Bartel sees improved game sales this fall and holiday season thanks to new consoles and VR game gear and highly anticipated game software titles like Activision's (ATVI) "Call of Duty: Infinite War," EA's (EA) "Battlefield 1" and Nintendo's (NTDOY) "Pokemon Sun and Moon."RELATED:GameStop Gobbles 507 AT&T Mobility Stores In Diversification Move'Pokemon Go' On $1 Billion-Plus Annual Revenue Run Rate

Exchange traded funds tracking major stock indexes inched higher Tuesday as investors digested key earnings results and upbeat housing data while awaiting a speech from Fed Chair Janet Yellen later this week.The Nasdaq composite index pegged a fresh all-time intraday high of 5275.74.Consumer-focused ETFs flew higher, with Best Buy (BBY) shares soaring on a strong quarterly report. The stock gapped up to add nearly 20% after the electronics retailer disclosed a 16% jump in year-over-year profits and modest sales gain.SPDR S&P Retail (XRT) sped up 1.0% on the stock market today as Best Buy's earnings beat buoyed the retail sector. The equal-weighted ETF counts Best Buy among its 95 stock holdings.Another consumer-focused sector also muscled higher on news that U.S. single-family new home sales in July hit their highest level in nearly nine years.Amid a brighter outlook for the housing market, iShares U.S. Home Construction (ITB) rose 2.6% and SPDR S&P Homebuilders (XHB) 1.8%.Materials led advancing S&P 500 sectors, rising 0.9%. Utilities led declining sectors, down 0.4%.IBD'S TAKE: Best Buy's results are even more impressive given that the retailer was competing against Amazon.com's (AMZN) Prime Day promotions and a steady drip of discounts from Wal-Mart Stores (WMT).In other ETF market action, United States Oil (USO) rallied 1.1%, after breaking a string of seven straight gains with a 3% decline Monday. Reuters reported Tuesday that Iran has signaled it may support efforts to prop up oil prices.USO, a commodity ETF, invests in oil futures.Here's how major exchange traded funds across major asset classes performed today, with IBD RS ratings.The RS (Relative Price Strength) rating is a measure of a stock's price performance over the last 12 months, compared to all stocks and ETFs, on a scale of 1 to a best-possible 99.Following daily ETF market action can be key to successful investing:SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), +0.2%, RS 55PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), +0.2%, RS 62SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA), +0.1%, RS 55IShares Core S&P Mid-Cap (IJH), +0.5%, RS 62IShares Russell 2000 (IWM), +0.7%, RS 65IShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), +0.4%, RS 34Vanguard FTSE Emerging Markets (VWO), -0.5%, RS 74SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), 0%, RS 68United States Oil (USO), +1.1%, RS 20IShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond (AGG), 0%, RS 34PowerShares DB U.S.$ Bullish (UUP), -0.1%, RS 21IPath S&P 500 VIX Short-Term Futures (VXX), -0.2%, RS 1

Consumer electronics retailer Best Buy (BBY) saw its shares gap higher on Tuesday after the company reported better-than-expected sales and earnings for its fiscal second quarter.Best Buy stock soared 19.6% to 39.23 on the stock market today, notching a 17-month high.The Richfield, Minn.-based company earned 57 cents a share excluding items on sales of $8.53 billion in its fiscal Q2 ended July 30. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting 43 cents EPS on $8.4 billion in sales.On a year-over-year basis, earnings per share jumped 16% and sales rose a fraction.Best Buy surprised Wall Street with an increase in same-store sales. Comparable sales rose 0.8% in Q2. Analysts had projected a 0.6% decrease in same-store sales, Bloomberg reported. The company credited rising demand for wearable technology, appliances, computers and home-theater systems for the increase, which was partially offset by declines in mobile phones and video games.Best Buy Chief Financial Officer Corie Barry said she expects comparable-store sales to be up about 1% in Q3.Best Buy is targeting Q3 EPS of 43 to 47 cents, in line with consensus estimates for 45 cents.Best Buy management has been cutting costs, closing underperforming stores and selling foreign divisions to boost profits. The company also has bucked up its e-commerce operations, with U.S. online sales up 24% in Q2."We are encouraged by the quality of our execution, the momentum in our business and the strength of our first-half financial results," Best Buy CEO Hubert Joly said in a statement.Best Buy's cheery Q2 report lifted other electronics retailers, including GameStop (GME), Conn's (CONN) and Hhgregg (HGG). GameStop rose 2%. Conn's ended the day up a fraction. And Hhgregg moved 4.4% higher.IBD'S TAKE: Best Buy is in IBD's Retail-Consumer Electronics group, which ranks a lowly No. 188 out of 197 groups. GameStop is the top-ranked stock in the group, but it has a low IBD Composite Rating of 29. Consult IBD Stock Checkup to find leading stocks.RELATED:Fitbit, Garmin, GoPro Get Lift From Best Buy's Q2 Earnings Report

The S&P 500 climbed 0.2% as it too trimmed gains. It came just shy of making its own record high. The small-cap Russell 2000 led with a 0.7% increase. Both…

Stocks rallied in early trading Tuesday on the back of a solid earnings report from Best Buy (BBY) and an announcement by Mobileye (MBLY) and Delphi (DLPH) that brings the dream of driverless cars closer to reality.The Nasdaq rose 0.4%, pulling back somewhat after hitting an all-time intraday high. The S&P 500 rose 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.25% in the stock market today. Volume was lighter than the same time Monday on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq.Mobileye briefly topped a 50.28 buy point, currently up 7% to 49.81 in big volume. Mobileye and Delphi agreed to develop a fully autonomous vehicle that will be demonstrated at the 2017 Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas in January and will be production-ready in 2019. Delphi jumped 3%. Mobileye recently ended a partnership with Tesla Motors (TSLA), and has a separate BMW-Intel alliance to have a driverless car by 2021.Mobileye was the best performer in the IBD 50, where 47 stocks were higher and three were lower.Best Buy gapped up and was trading 17.5% higher after reporting adjusted Q2 earnings of 57 cents a share, beating Wall Street estimates of 45 cents. Revenue came in at $8.53 billion vs. estimates of $8.4 billion. Best Buyguided Q3 in line with estimates.Oil rebounded in late morning trade on reports that Iran might be willing to freeze production, with U.S. crude moving back above $48 a barrel. Earlier, oil prices sank below $47 on Goldman Sachs arguing that an OPEC freeze wouldn't boost prices.Momo (MOMO), a mobile-based social networking platform in China, soared 16%.RELATED:

Last week's disappointing earnings report from discount retailer Target (TGT) has cast a shadow over this week's reports from electronics retailers Best Buy (BBY) and GameStop (GME).Last Wednesday, Target slashed its earnings expectations for the rest of the year, citing a "challenging environment."Target said it has experienced meaningful pressure in electronics, marked by a double-digit comp sales decline. About a third of that pressure is due to declining sales of Apple (AAPL) products.IBD'S TAKE: Best Buy and GameStop are 2 of 6 stocks in IBD's Retail-Consumer Electronics group, which ranks No. 180 out of 197 groups. GameStop is the top-ranked stock in the group, but it has a low IBD Composite Rating of 29. For more information, check out the IBD Stock Checkup.Best Buy is scheduled to report its fiscal-second-quarter results before the stock market opens Tuesday. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Best Buy to earn 43 cents a share, down 12% year over year, on sales of $8.4 billion, down 2%, in fiscal Q2.For its fiscal Q3, Wall Street is modeling for Best Buy to earn 45 cents a share, up 10%, on sales of $8.77 billion, down less than 1%.Wedbush Securities analyst Michael Pachter said Best Buy faces declining sales due to a lack of compelling new products."Declining sales present a more formidable headwind, and continuing cost cuts remain elusive," he said in a research report last week.UBS analyst Michael Lasser concurred that consumer electronics sales remain weak, though sales of 4K TVs appear to be heating up.Video game and electronics retailer GameStop is set to release its fiscal Q2 results after the market close on Thursday.Analysts are looking for GameStop to earn 27 cents a share, down 13%, on sales of $1.72 billion, down 2%.For the current quarter, Wall Street forecasts GameStop to earn 53 cents a share, down 2%, on sales of $2.07 billion, up 3%.GameStop has been diversifying from video game shops to stores dedicated to selling mobile devices, Apple products and pop-culture collectibles.In a research report Sunday, Pacific Crest Securities analyst Evan Wilson said NPD retail data point to a weak quarter for physical game software sales. The massive popularity of the free-to-play smartphone game "Pokemon Go" from Niantic likely hurt physical software sales in July, he said. Use and engagement of "Pokemon Go" is slowing, however, Bloomberg reported Monday.Wall Street's focus Thursday will be on GameStop's second-half 2016 guidance, including the holiday shopping season, investment bank Credit Suisse said in a report Monday.Sales of virtual reality gaming gear could provide upside to Q4 results, Credit Suisse said.Best Buy stock rose a fraction Monday to 32.80 and is up 8% this year, while GameStock stock fell a fraction in the stock market today, though it's up 11% so far in 2016.RELATED:Most-Anticipated Video Game Is Out Of This WorldGameStop Gobbles 507 AT&T Mobility Stores In Diversification MoveBest Buy Latest Retailer To Disappoint, Gives Soft Profit Outlook.

It was an innovation that stood pretty much alone in the wearable technology market for nearly 200 years. Consumer electronics retailer Best Buy (BBY) received several price target hikes to its stock on Wednesday, a day after posting better-than-expected second-quarter earnings. Meanwhile, GPS device maker Garmin (GRMN) was downgraded, and coverage of discount retailer Five Below (FIVE) was initiated with a neutral rating.In the wake of its positive Q2 report, Best Buy earned price target increases from RBC Capital Markets, Telsey Advisory Group and Deutsche Bank.RBC maintained its sector perform rating on Best Buy but upped its price target on the stock to 42 from 36. On Tuesday, Best Buy stock rose nearly 20% to 39.23, and added another 0.7% Wednesday to close at 39.50 on the stock market today.Telsey reiterated its outperform rating on Best Buy and also raised its price target to 42 from 36.Deutsche maintained its hold rating on Best Buy, but increased its price target to 41 from 30.Investment banks UBS and Citigroup maintained their neutral ratings on the stock. UBS has a price target on Best Buy of 38, while Citigroup is at 40.RELATED:Best Buy Stock Jumps On Q2 Earnings Beat As Same-Store Sales RiseGoldman Sachs advised clients Wednesday to exit Garmin stock. The investment bank cut its rating on Garmin to sell from hold with a price target of 46.Garmin, which makes GPS devices along with wearable activity trackers and sports watches, tumbled 5.7% to 50.59 Wednesday. The stock climbed nearly 1% to 53.67 on Tuesday after Best Buy's report.RELATED:Garmin Stock Cut To Sell By Goldman Sachs On Fitness HeadwindsFitbit, Garmin, GoPro Get Lift From Best Buy's Q2 Earnings ReportBTIG Research started coverage of Five Below with a neutral rating. Five Below is on the IBD 50 list of top-performing stocks.The Philadelphia-based teen-oriented specialty discounter fell 2.1% to end at 47.14 after rising 3.5% to 48.15 on Tuesday. Five Below stock hit a more than two-year high of 52.70 on July 27.Goldman Sachs resumed coverage on defense and aerospace company Lockheed Martin (LMT) with a neutral rating and a price target of 245.Lockheed stock fell 0.65% to 248.12, falling as low as 244.80, briefly undercutting a 245.47 buy point. It hit a record high of 266.93 on Aug. 15.RELATED:Lockheed F-35 'On A Path Toward Failing To Deliver' Full CapabilityLockheed Martin Stock Fails To Defend Key Support LineHome builder Toll Brothers (TOL) received a price target increase on Wednesday from RBC Capital Markets. RBC maintained its sector perform rating on Toll but raised its target on the stock to 35 from 32.Toll Brothers fell 2.8% to 31.03. It rose 8.8% to 31.91 on Tuesday after the Horsham, Pa.-based luxury builder reported double-digit profit and revenue growth in the second quarter as the housing market continues its recovery.RELATED:July Existing Home Sales Fall 3.2% To 5.39 Million PaceToll Bros. Leads Builders As New-Home Sales Rocket To 8-Year High

Investment bank Goldman Sachs on Wednesday lowered its rating on Garmin (GRMN) stock to sell from hold on concerns of slowing growth in its wearable fitness device business.Garmin stock fell 5.7% to 50.59 on the stock market today. Shares had hit a six-month high above 56 on Aug. 1.On Tuesday, Garmin rose nearly 1% to 53.67 after retailer Best Buy (BBY) called out wearables as one of its hottest product categories. Goldman has a price target of 46 on Garmin."We expect shares to underperform from here as the key Fitness/Outdoor segment slows from 29% growth in Q2 2016 to (an estimated) 7% in Q2 2017," Goldman analyst Simona Jankowski said in a report.In the next few months, Garmin will face increased competition from rivals launching new devices, she said.Fitbit (FIT) is expected to unveil the Fitbit Charge 2 and Fitbit Flex 2 activity tracking bands in September.Apple (AAPL) this fall is expected to launch its second-generation smartwatch, the Apple Watch 2, which will include improved health and fitness features.But Jankowski sees fitness trackers losing steam this holiday shopping season."While fitness products were a hot seller over the past two holiday seasons, this holiday season they will see increased competition for consumer wallets from a few new emerging consumer electronics categories, including virtual reality headsets, home assistants and drones," she said.Among the products vying for consumer dollars this Christmas will be VR headsets from Sony (SNE) and Facebook's (FB) Oculus unit, new action cameras such as the Samsung Gear 360 and GoPro (GPRO) Hero 5, flying-camera drones like GoPro's Karma and DJI's Phantom 4, and voice-activated personal assistant speakers like Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google Home and Amazon.com's (AMZN) Echo.IBD'S TAKE: With its continued strong growth, Amazon.com has been a mainstay on IBD Leaderboard. But the stock is more than 20% extended from its last buy point, and many leading stocks will begin to consolidate after such a gain.Garmin also will face a period of difficult comparisons to its own strong product cycle, which included the Elevate wrist-based heart monitor technology, Jankowski said.Meanwhile, Garmin rival Fitbit saw its shares climb about 2% in midday trading Wednesday, after it won a positive ruling in a legal battle with Jawbone.The International Trade Commission on Tuesday issued an initial determination in favor of Fitbit in an ITC case brought by Jawbone. The administrative law judge who presided over the merits hearing concluded that Fitbit did not misappropriate any Jawbone trade secrets as Jawbone had alleged.

Stocks ended modestly higher Tuesday after sales of new homes rose more than expected last month. Toll Bros. (TOL) and KB Home (KBH) led gains by homebuilders.The Nasdaq climbed 0.3%, the S&P 500 added 0.2%, and the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1%. Volume was mixed in the stock market today, rising 7% on the NYSE and falling 2% on the Nasdaq compared to Monday, according to preliminary data.Tesla Motors (TSLA) rose 1% after saying it will launch a battery capable of taking an electric car 315 miles on a single charge, the longest range of any electric vehicle.The stock ended the day 17% off its 52-week high as it gets support at its 50-day moving average.After the close, La-Z-Boy (LZB) plunged 16% after investors panned its latest quarterly earnings report. The stock had risen more than 3% during the regular session, hitting a new high.The company said same-store sales fell 1.9% during the quarter, down from a 5.3% gain a year earlier.Intuit (INTU) slid more than 3% in post-session trading after the maker of TurboTax software issued a weak outlook for the current quarter.In the regular session, retailers were among the day's biggest gainers, led by Best Buy (BBY), which soared 19% to a 52-week high following a blowout quarterly earnings report.Homebuilders got a boost from a strong earnings report from Toll Bros and a 12% jump in July new-home sales. Toll jumped 9%, and KB Home climbed 5%.Meanwhile, Workday (WDAY), PVH (PVH), HP Inc. (HPQ) and Royal Bank of Canada (RY) are among companies due to report quarterly earnings Wednesday.Economic data due Wednesday include the Mortgage Bankers Association's index of mortgage applications for the week ended Aug. 20, the FHFA's home price index for June, existing-home sales for July, and weekly crude oil inventories.

Consumer electronics retailer Best Buy (BBY) roared 19% higher on Tuesday morning after a surprise jump in its online sales helped send its second-quarter sales and earnings above analysts' targets. Best Buy's brick-and-mortar retail chain model has been fighting a long-term battle vs. online retailers, a battle that has been recently complicated by some slowing trends in consumer electronics purchases.…

Wearable device makers Fitbit (FIT), Garmin (GRMN) and GoPro (GPRO) saw their shares rise on Tuesday after consumer electronics retailer Best Buy (BBY) reported better-than-expected fiscal Q2 sales.Best Buy management pointed to wearables as one of the company's growth segments, sparking a surprise increase in same-store sales in the quarter ended July 30.Fitbit, which makes wearable fitness trackers, saw its shares rise 3.1% to 14.88 on the stock market today.Garmin, which makes GPS devices along with wearable activity trackers and sports watches, saw its stock climb nearly 1% to 53.67 on Tuesday.GoPro, which makes wearable action cameras, ended the day up 2% to 15.51.Best Buy shares shot up nearly 20% on Tuesday.IBD'S TAKE: IBD's Computer Products-Electronic group ranks No. 21 out of 197 industry groups. The top-ranked company in the group is remote-control maker Universal Electronics. For a tutorial on How to Find and Evaluate Stocks, check out the IBD University.Fitbit, Garmin and GoPro are gearing up for the holiday shopping season. Health and fitness devices are expected to remain hot categories this Christmas. Fitbit is widely expected to release several new devices this fall. Meanwhile, GoPro is scheduled to release its Hero 5 camera and Karma flying-camera drone this holiday season.Other companies chasing the hot wearables category include watchmaker Fossil Group (FOSL) and Apple (AAPL), which sell smartwatches. Apple is rumored to be releasing its second-generation Apple Watch this fall.Fossil rose 1% while Apple climbed fractionally.RELATED:

Best Buy's brick-and-mortar retail chain model has been fighting a long-term battle vs. online retailers, a battle that has been recently complicated by some slowing trends in consumer electronics purchases.…

Stock indexes remained higher Tuesday, improving somewhat from an early-afternoon lull.The Nasdaq climbed 0.4% but had been up by as much as 0.6%, hitting a record intraday high. The S&P 500 was up 0.3%, and the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.2%. Small caps led as the Russell 2000 jumped 0.9%.Volume was tracking higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq. Advancing stocks led decliners on the Nasdaq on the stock market today.A bullish report on the housing market appeared to spark institutional buying in homebuilding, construction and mortgage stocks. New-home sales soared 31.3% in July, hitting a new post-recession high of 654,000 at an annualized rate. The number was well above the 580,000 economists expected.PulteGroup (PHM) jumped 2.6% in heavy trading. The stock has been consolidating for more than three weeks in what could be interpreted as the handle of long base with a 22.50 buy point.Toll Brothers (TOL) roared 8% higher in big volume as it was working its way back from a deep decline. The luxury-home builder matched earnings estimates in its report Tuesday and edged past revenue views.D.R. Horton (DHI), a leader in the homebuilding group, jumped back above the 32.20 buy point of a pattern it cleared initially July 6. KB Home (KBH) vaulted 5% as it rallied from support at the 50-day moving average. Thinly traded M/I Homes (MHO) broke out past the 23.24 buy point of a cup with handle.IBD's mortgage industry group rose 1.8% as LendingTree (TREE) climbed back above a 104.36 entry, trading up 5%. The homebuilding, wood products and building products industry groups all added more than 1% apiece.Retail was another hot sector following a surprisingly strong quarterly report from electronics chain Best Buy (BBY).Five Below (FIVE) climbed nearly 4% and made it back to its 50-day moving average. Ulta Beauty (ULTA) stretched its long advance with a gain of nearly 2% in volume about 20% above normal. Big Lots (BIG) bounced nearly 5% in volume 55% more than average after falling back to a 53.45 buy point.At Home Group (HOME) broke out of an IPO base past a 16.58 buy point intraday, and is now up nearly 10% at 16.45. The operator of more than 100 large-format furniture stores went public Aug. 4 at 15 a share.RELATED:New-Home Sales Surge In July, Beating ForecastsBest Buy Rises After Profit Beat Boosts Confidence In Turnaround.

Here's your Investing Action Plan for Tuesday: What you need to know as an investor for the coming day.Earnings reports from Dycom Industries (DY), J.M. Smucker (SJM), Toll Brothers (TOL) and Best Buy (BBY) are on tap, new-home sales from the Commerce Department are due, and Line Corp. (LN) and Veeva Systems (VEEV) could flash important stock signals.Estimates: Analysts see the installer of fiber optic wiring reporting a 69% jump in fiscal Q4 earnings to 61 cents per share. Revenue is seen rising 21.2% to $1.25 billion.Prior Quarter: In Q3, EPS jumped 86.2% to $1.80, on a 35% increase in revenue to $664.65 million.Stock: The Leaderboard name triggered sell signal on Aug. 11, falling below its 50-day line after Alphabet (GOOGL) unit Google announced its fiber optic building "pause." But shares have risen for the past four sessions, climbing 3.8% on Monday to 91.30, back above the 50-day.Why It Matters: Web video is driving the need for faster internet speeds now forcing telecom customers to boost investment in fiber optic wiring. Dycom's stock has climbed over 20% this year, thanks to surging revenue from telecom customers like AT&T (T) and Alphabet driving earnings growth.IBD'S TAKE: Dycom is No. 2 on  IBD's Telecom-Infrastructure group, with a 96 Composite Rating, just behind Ubiquiti Networks. Learn more about Ubiquiti and other top stocks in the group with IBD's Stock Checkup. Estimates: The packaged food maker is expected to report a 31.8% increase in Q1 EPS to $1.74, but sales are seen falling 3% to $1.89 billion.Prior Quarter: In Q4, EPS jumped 47% to $1.44, and its sales were up 25% to $1.8 billion.Stock: Smucker broke out of a flat base in June and is getting support at its 50-day moving average, rising 1.05% to 156.23 on Monday.Why It Matters: Three of the last four times Smucker reported earnings, shares rose sharply.Estimates:  Q2 EPS is seen falling 12.2% to 43 cents, with sales down 1.6% to $8.4 billion.Prior Quarter: Q1 EPS climbed 19% to 44 cents, while sales dipped 1% to $8.44 billion.Stock: Best Buy is falling back towards its 50-day and 200-day lines, but rose 0.6% to 32.80 on Monday.Why It Matters: Best Buy has struggled in recent quarters. But earlier, the company said it expected to return to sales growth in the second half of the fiscal year. Will growth in the wearable fitness, home theater and appliances categories be enough to offset slowdowns in smartphone and PC sales? Best Buy's results will indicate demand for a slew of consumer electronics makers.Estimates: Q3 EPS is expected to jump 69% to 61 cents, as revenue rises 21.2% to $1.25 billion.Prior Quarter: In Q2, the homebuilder's EPS rose 38% to 51 cents, as revenue was up 31% to $1.11 billion.Stock: Toll Bros. has already cleared its 50-day line and is headed towards its 200-day line. Toll Bros. rose 1.9% to 29.33.Why It Matters: Luxury builder Toll Bros. is a bellwether in the housing industry and could offer investors a good idea on how things are faring.The Commerce Department is expected announce a dip in July new-home sales figures, according to a note by Societe Generale. In June, new-home sales were up 3.5%. Existing-home sales data are due to be released Wednesday.RELATED:

McDonald's (MCD) and Best Buy (BBY) were downgraded Monday, while Lululemon (LULU) and JCPenney (JCP) saw their price targets raised, and Valeant (VRX) was upgraded to buy.McDonald's was downgraded to hold from buy at Argus. The fast-food giant's profit margins are likely to be squeezed by rising labor costs and slowing same-store growth over the coming quarters. McDonald's last month posted weaker-than-expected U.S. comps, something several other restaurants have also reported.McDonald's stock lost 0.8% to 118.52 at the close on the stock market today.Telsey Advisory Group raised Lululemon's price target to 92 from 82 and kept its outperform rating on the yoga-wear retailer's stock.Lululemon shares rose 1.2% to 80.27 at the close, hitting a three-year high.Best Buy was downgraded to hold with a 36 price target at Jefferies. The analysts said that the electronics store will see weaker same-store sales and margins due to a "maturing" 4K TV cycle.Best Buy shares fell 1% to 34.51. The stock is at a resistance area around 35.Nordstrom's (JWN) price target was raised to 47 from 38 at RBC Capital Markets. Late Thursday, the upscale department store reported better-than-expected profit in Q2, but revenue came in light. Still, Nordstrom rose 8% on Friday and was up 18% for the week.Telsey Advisory hiked JCPenney's price target to 13 from 12. On Friday, JCPenney reported a smaller-than-expected Q2 loss, as same-store sales rose 2.2%. JCPenney was the bright spot among department stores in Q2, according to Cowen analysts. JCPenney shares rose 6% on Friday and 12% for the week.Nordstrom shares rose 3.1% to 52.96 intraday. JCPenney stock jumped 7% to 11.29.IBD'S TAKE: Nordstrom and JCPenney are rebounding, but they are still working on bases while their fundamentals are mixed. Meanwhile, Home Depot and Lowe's are holding at or near buy points, as their profit and sales have held up. For more on the home improvement chains, which both report earnings this week, click here.The drugmaker was upgraded to neutral by Mizuho Securities. Valeant is still dealing with a scandal with now-defunct pharmacy Philidor.On Monday, billionaire investor David Tepper's Appaloosa hedge fund disclosed it sold off all its shares of Valeant in Q2.Valeant shares leapt 6.7% to 26.59 at the close.

Best Buy (BBY) rose as much as 16% in early trading after posting second-quarter results that topped analysts' estimates, boosting confidence that Chief Executive Hubert Joly can return the largest U.S. electronics retailer to consistent growth.Profit was 57 cents a share, excluding some items, the Richfield, Minn.-based company said Tuesday in a statement. Analysts projected 43 cents, on average. The stock climbed as high as $38.06 before the start of regular trading in New York.The results signal that Joly may finally be turning around the chain after years of sluggish growth. Though online competition and a weakening electronics industry have made it tough to boost revenue, Joly has kept Best Buy profitable by selling foreign divisions and cutting costs.The company even managed to eke out a sales gain last quarter, helped by rising demand for wearable technology, appliances and home-theater gear. Revenue of $8.53 billion was about $5 million higher than a year earlier and surpassed analysts' $8.39 billion average estimate.Comparable sales rose 0.8%, while analysts' had projected a 0.6% decrease, according to Consensus Metrix.IBD'S TAKE: Best Buy is in IBD's Retail-Consumer Electronics group, which ranks No. 180 out of 197 groups. GameStop is the top-ranked stock in the group, but it has a low IBD Composite Rating of 29. Consult IBD Stock Checkup to find leading stocks.The results are even more impressive, given that Best Buy was competing against Amazon.com's (AMZN) Prime Day promotions and a "steady diet" of discounts from Wal-Mart Stores (WMT), said Charlie O'Shea, an analyst at Moody's Investors Service. Best Buy's online sales growth of 24% was also "impressive," O'Shea said.Best Buy's second-quarter performance "is evidence that a well-managed brick-and-mortar retailer with a well-thought-out strategy that successfully utilizes its physical assets can thrive as it transitions to a true multi-channel retailer," he said.

Stock indexes opened higher Tuesday, with the Dow industrials and Nasdaq up 0.5% and the S&P 500 climbing 0.4%. The Nasdaq has hit a record high, with the other major indexes close to all-time bests.The always-volatile Best Buy (BBY) sparked nearly 16% higher after its second-quarter earnings soared past expectations. Revenue eased but online sales jumped 24%, while same-store sales eked up 0.8%, vs. guidance for flat performance.Seed strain and herbicide maker Monsanto (MON) climbed 4% early. The company reiterated its full-year earnings guidance and repeated that it remained open to merger discussions with Germany's Bayer (BAYRY) and others.Homebuilder Toll Brothers (TOL) added 1.5% after reporting its fiscal third quarter earnings met views and revenue narrowly beat estimates.IBD 50 stock Mobileye (MBLY) tacked on a 7% gain. The Israel-based tech announced it would partner with General Motors (GM) electronics supplier Delphi Automotive (DLPH) to develop off-the-shelf autonomous driving technologies for automakers. Mobileye is testing support at its 10-week moving average, though it's below a 50.28 buy point in a cup-with-handle base. Delphi shares also rose 3% after the open.Packaging maker Sealed Air (SEE) climbed more than 2%. UBS initiated coverage with a buy rating and a 54 price target.J.M. Smucker (SJM) dropped nearly 8%.  The Orrville, Ohio, jam maker reported stronger-than-forecast earnings, but revenue growth missed analyst targets. The stock has been finding support at the 10-week moving average and is up 27% since the start of the year.London-based researcher Markit said the eurozone's post-Brexit pulse remained stable, putting its preliminary Eurozone Purchasing Managers' Index at 53.3 in August, vs. a 53.2 final reading for July. France's private sector increased at the sharpest rate in 10 months, although German economic growth eased to its slowest pace in two months. The CAC 40 in Paris was up 0.8% and the DAX in Frankfurt climbed 0.9% in afternoon trade.Markit's PMI for Japan showed manufacturing output topping the 50 level that indicates expansion for the first time since February. Tokyo's Nikkei 225, which closed before the data release, ended Tuesday's session down 0.6%.July new-home sales numbers from the Commerce Department are due out at 10 a.m. ET.Oil futures eased 1% early Tuesday after Monday's 3% slide. West Texas Intermediate crude futures traded around $47 a barrel. Gold gained a fraction to $1,348 an ounce. The dollar pulled back from its recent gains and bonds flattened.

The major averages ended mixed in a nearly flat session Monday, as biotech stocks rose to help offset declines in the oil sector.The Nasdaq edged up 0.1%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each dipped 0.1%. Volume fell on both the Nasdaq and the NYSE compared to Friday, according to preliminary data.After the close, Zoe's Kitchen (ZOES) plunged 10% following its quarterly earnings report. The fast-casual Mediterranean-style restaurant chain closed the regular trading session 10% off its 52-week high and has been consolidating since early April.Elsewhere in the stock market today, biotech stock Medivation (MDVN) rocketed nearly 20% skyward after Pfizer (PFE) announced plans to buy the maker of cancer drugs for $14 billion. For its own part, Pfizer dipped a fraction.IBD'S TAKE: Want to know how Pfizer stacks up against other stocks in its industry? Find out at IBD's Stock Checkup.The deal news helped boost IBD's biomedical industry group 2%.Amphastar Pharmaceuticals (AMPH) jumped 3% to a new high in heavy volume. The maker of drugs to treat diabetes, asthma and other diseases is out of buying range after clearing a 17.90 buy point of a long, deep cup-with-handle base.Meanwhile, oil producer Denbury Resources (DNR) dropped nearly 6%, leading the S&P 500 lower, as crude prices sank 3%.Dycom (DY), Best Buy (BBY), J.M. Smucker (SJM) and Toll Bros. (TOL) are among companies reporting quarterly earnings Tuesday.Economic data due Tuesday include new-home sales for July.

The strong performances of Acacia Communications (ACIA), Twilio (TWLO) and a couple of other recent initial public offerings sets a path for closely watched Nutanix to make its public debut.Nutanix initially filed IPO registration plans last December with the intent to come public early this year, but it held back due to weak IPO market conditions. Initial public offerings hit a seven-year low in the first quarter, but the IPO market rebounded in the second quarter.Acacia stock jumped 35% in its May 13 debut and is now trading near 118 after pricing its initial shares at 23. Twilio priced at 15 and popped 92% on its first day of trading, June 23. Twilio stock now trades near 59. Acacia stock rose 2.45% to 117.59 in the stock market today, while Twilio stock was up 6.9%. Twilio makes cloud-based communications software, while Acacia provides high-speed fiber optic communications gear.Other strong-performing IPOs include Impinj (PI), a provider of radio-frequency identification tags and reader chips; Talend (TLND), a Big Data and cloud integration software maker; and mobile messaging company Line (LN).Impinj is up 52% from its July 21 IPO. Talend, which debuted July 28, is up nearly 66%. Talend reports earnings after the market close on ThursdayLine is up 40%.Nutanix provides an enterprise cloud platform that converges servers, storage resources and virtualization software into one integrated solution. Its platform can connect to public cloud services.For the nine months ended April 30, Nutanix reported revenue of $305.1 million, up 82% year over year. It had a net loss of $118.6 million vs. a net loss of $88.9 million in the same period a year earlier, as the company continues to spend heavily on expansion. Nutanix said it expects to continue to incur losses "for the foreseeable future."Nutanix customers include Activision Blizzard (ATVI), Best Buy (BBY), Jabil Circuit (JBL) and Kellog (K).IBD'S TAKE: New issues like Acacia and Twilio can be great stock winners, as the companies are typically in a fast-growth phase. But not all recent IPOs are great stocks. Check out IBD's IPO Leaders screen for top performers. San Jose, Calif.-based Nutanix was founded in 2009. The lead underwriters for the IPO are Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan.Though the company has its IPO prospectus on file with the SEC, its IPO is not imminent. Nutanix has yet to set an price range or begin a road show with institutional investors.RELATED:
